p.text: [p]You're off to visit your grandmother, whose house hacks up to a graveyard. At first the tombstones seem far away. But every day they move a little closer. Then you discover the headstones are disappearing. But the dead aren't gone – their ghosts are moving. Right into your grandmother's house![/p] [p]If you decide to stay, you must battle a warrior ghost. If you decide to run, one of the kid ghosts follows you home. Will you be haunted... for the rest of your life?[/p]

[p]You can’t believe it! You stare out the window at the creepy cemetery in your grandmother’s backyard. The graves are moving! You’re sure of it. Then you turn to see an even more frightening sight – your grandmother’s house is haunted by ghosts. Lots of ghosts. Evil ghosts who want you![/p] [p]Why are the creeping coffins creeping? Do you stay to find out or do you race home – even though a terrifying ghost is waiting for you there, too?[/p] [p]If you stay you discover that the coffins are spelling a message in the graveyard – a message that spells out your doom. Unless you can find the ghost who is the Keeper of the Sword, steal the sword, and plunge it into the grave of the MPG! What’s an MPG? You’ll have to find out for yourself – but hurry, the ghosts are moving closer and closer...[/p]

[p]“I'm bored,” you moan. “I’m so bored, I could eat flies. Just to see how they taste.”[/p] [p]“Flies have germs,” your grandmother replies.[/p] [p]It is a hot, sticky day in the middle of July. You plop down into a creaky old chair in your grandmother’s kitchen. Your parents dropped you off yesterday, before they left for their vacation. And already you could die of boredom.[/p] [p]Your grandmother’s old dog, Sparkle, yawns loudly. He crawls under the table. Moments later, he begins to snore.[/p] [p]“I know just how you feel, Sparkle,” you say. You sigh loudly.[/p] [p]“Why don’t you go outside and find something to do?” your grandmother suggests. She looks up from the pie she’s baking and nods toward the backyard.[/p] [p]Go out there? you think. Into her backyard? No way.[/p] [p]You glance out the window. It’s probably ninety degrees in the shade, but you shiver. Your grandmother’s house is right in front of an old cemetery. Rows and rows of old, crumbling tombstones sit just beyond the edge of her backyard.[/p] [p]But that’s not what scares you.[/p] [p]What scares you is that the tombstones have been moving![/p]

[p]You noticed it right after you arrived yesterday.[/p] [p]You saw the tombstones from your bedroom window on the second floor. You could tell some of the graves had cool carvings on them, so you decided to go outside and take a closer look.[/p] [p]But when you entered the graveyard, something was different. Strange.[/p] [p]Some of the graves were out of place.[/p] [p]Nah, can’t be, you told yourself. Graves don’t disappear.[/p] [p]But still...[/p] [p]From your bedroom window, you could have sworn there were six or seven graves in the back row.[/p] [p]Now there were only three![/p] [p]Nah.... You must have counted wrong. You decided to forget it and went to bed.[/p] [p]But when you woke up this morning and glanced out the window, the coffins had moved again.[/p] [p]Now there were ten in the back row! And the middle rows seemed more crowded. It almost looked as if some of the graves were moving forward and some of the graves were moving backward, and there was a big traffic jam in the center.[/p] [p]The coffins were rearranging themselves![/p] [p]But how? And why?[/p]

[p]Your grandmother taps you on the shoulder. She snaps you out of your daydream. “Go on,” she says. “Go play outside.”[/p] [p]Outside? Out [em]there?[/em] You shudder as you glance out the kitchen window again. “Oh, no,” you cry. “It’s disappeared!”[/p] [p]“What’s disappeared?” your grandmother asks.[/p] [p]“The grave with the angel on it!” you screech, pointing out the window. “It’s gone!”[/p] [p]One headstone in particular caught your eye yesterday. It had an angel carving on it. The angel looked so realistic you practically believed she could fly away.[/p] [p]Did she?[/p] [p]Your grandmother peers out the kitchen window. “Don’t be a goose,” she scolds you. “That tombstone is still there.”[/p] [p]You don’t answer her. You can’t. Your heart is pounding crazily and your mouth has gone dry. You bolt out the back door. You’ve got to see for yourself.[/p] [p]But in the graveyard you discover that your grandmother is right. The tombstone with the angel isn’t gone.[/p] [p]It just moved![/p] [p]It had been in the last row. Now it’s up front.[/p] [p]I’m losing my mind, you think. Losing it completely.[/p] [p]Or are you?[/p] [p]Find it out.[/p]

[p]You run back into the house shouting.[/p] [p]“Grandma!” you yell. “That grave with the angel on it –”[/p] [p]Your grandmother interrupts you. “You don’t have to shout, dear. The angel?” She looks up from her pie crust. “That’s a nice one. Let me see. Who was buried there? Oh, yes. That’s Elmyra Martin’s grave.”[/p] [p]Before you can explain about the moving gravestones, a voice on the far side of the room makes you jump. “The name is [em]Elvira[/em] Martin,” the voice says sharply. “Not Elmyra. You never [em]could[/em] get my name right!”[/p] [p]Your mouth drops open. A strange woman now stands in the doorway that leads from the kitchen into the hall.[/p] [p]A very strange woman. Because she isn’t a living, breathing woman. She’s a ghost![/p] [p]“Uh, Grandma... ?” you begin. But from the way your granny is humming to herself, you can tell she doesn’t hear or see this scary visitor.[/p] [p]“And don’t you stare at me, you little wretch,” the ghost says, pointing at you. “Or you’ll be sorry.”[/p] [p]What are you going to do? Suddenly you’re living in a haunted house![/p]
p.next: If you run outside
If you talk to the ghost

p.text: [p]To your amazement, it works! The horse grows smaller.[/p] [p]Hey – cool![/p] [p]You push the volume button down again. Like magic, the ghost-horse grows even smaller.[/p] [p]“Wow!” you shout. You start pushing other buttons on the TV remote control. You can hardly wait to see what will happen![/p] [p]Unbelievably, when you press the channel button – the one that moves up to the next channel _ the ghost-horse changes into something else! A ghostly kung-fu master![/p] [p]When you press the button again, the kung-fu ghost changes into the ghost of an Egyptian pharaoh.[/p] [p]“This is amazing!” you exclaim.[/p] [p]Then you press it one more time.[/p] [p]Uh-oh. Big mistake.[/p]

[p]You turn and run from Lark. But he’s gaining on you. And his friends have joined in the chase.[/p] [p]“Let’s get those little creeps!” Lark’s friends are shouting.[/p] [p]You and Robin are skidding around a corner when you hear a voice whisper in your ear. “I’ll help you – on one condition. You have to promise to do whatever I ask tomorrow.”[/p] [p]It’s the ghost-boy! You can’t see him, but you heard his offer. What are you going to do?[/p]
p.next: If you accept the ghost’s offer
If not

p.text: [p]Yuck! Everything in the bucket spills all over your hair, head, face, shoulders, and shirt.[/p] [p]Raw eggs. Warm soda. Sour milk. Bread[/p] [p]crumbs. It’s disgusting.[/p] [p]Some used tissues are mixed in there, too.[/p] [p]“What did you do that for?” you yell angrily.[/p] [p]“You saw the sign,” Digger replies. “No trespassers. That means [em]you[/em].”[/p] [p]What a creep! you think. Digger is a total, certified jerk.[/p] [p]In other words, he’s just what you need to deal with this ghost![/p] [p]So what are you going to do? Keep climbing – and take your chances with Digger? Or face the ghost alone?[/p]
p.next: If you keep climbing
If you face the ghost alone

p.text: [p]The Luckmeyer twins? What are they up to now? you wonder.[/p] [p]As MacFarling drives off, you notice that the sky is growing dark. Night is falling and there’s a thin wispy ring of clouds around the moon.[/p] [p]An owl hoots nearby. Then it swoops towrard you! Its claws seem to be aimed right for your face![/p] [p]You duck – and feel the tip of its wing brush past your cheek. When you glance up, you notice a curtain moving in a window on the second floor of your grandmother’s house.[/p] [p]There they are! That teenage ghost and his twin sister with the braids wrapped around her head – Jane and John Luckmeyer! John points down at you and laughs evilly.[/p] [p]I hope [em]he’s[/em] not the Keeper of the Sword, you think.[/p] [p]Then you notice something strange up in the attic window. A light flickers on and off. On and off. Someone is up there. Is it the Keeper of the Sword?[/p] [p]There’s only one way to find out. You take a deep breath and head toward the house. The haunted house.[/p]
p.next: If you think John Luckmeyer is the Keeper of the Sword
If you think the Keeper of the Sword is hiding in the attic

p.text: [p]When the dust settles, you are stunned by what you see. Glory, the ghost stallion, has doubled in[/p] [p]size![/p] [p]And he was already a big horse.[/p] [p]“Neat trick,” your grandmother says. “That’s quite a gadget.” She gets up and heads for the kitchen. “I’m going for a soda,” she tells you. “Want one?”[/p] [p]“N-n-no th-thanks,” you stammer. You stare at Glory. The giant horse towers over you, pawing the rug.[/p] [p]“What button did you push?” you shout to your grandmother.[/p] [p]“Oh, I don’t know,” she calls back. “I think it was the one that turns up the sound.”[/p] [p]Okay, you think. Maybe if I turn the sound down...[/p] [p]Your finger hovers over the volume button. You hesitate. What if pushing the button will make the horse bigger? What if more ghost-horses appear?[/p] [p]Got a better idea?[/p] [p]You push the volume button. [em]Down[/em].[/p] [p]Push the button.[/p]

[p]You don’t exactly feel like practicing the piano right now. But you decide to be nice to this old woman. You go with her, and she leads you to a fancy old grand piano.[/p] [p]She sits you down and turns on a metronome.[/p] [p]TICK. TOCK. TICK. TOCK.[/p] [p]“Now play a G-major scale for me,” she says.[/p] [p]For the next half hour, you take a piano lesson. With a ghost! When you’re done, Mrs. Hatfield smiles.[/p] [p]“Remember how I always used to give you a treat at the end of your lesson?” she says. “Well, I have a treat for you now.”[/p] [p]“What’s this?” you ask as she hands you a piece of paper.[/p] [p]“It’s a map of my backyard,” she says. “You see, I buried a lot of gold out under the apple tree. And I forgot to mention it in my will. So no one knows it’s there. I want you to have it – as a reward for being so nice to me today. For letting me give you a piano lesson one more time.”[/p] [p]“Uh, bu-duh ... but... wow, thanks!” you mumble like an idiot.[/p] [p]Then it hits you. What good will the gold do you – if you’re a ghost?[/p]

[p]You climb the last steps of the ladder. You reach the tree house platform and pull yourself onto it.[/p] [p]“You don’t give up, do you?” Digger says, sounding mildly impressed.[/p] [p]“Never,” you say, trying to sound determined[/p] [p]and tough.[/p] [p]Digger brushes his long, greasy brown hair out of his eyes. He’s a thick, chunky kid with bad teeth and worse skin.[/p] [p]“So what do you want?” Digger asks you.[/p] [p]“A towel, for one thing,” you say, wiping off some of the yucky gunk he dumped on your head.[/p] [p]Digger throws you a rag. You try to clean yourself up. Then you look Digger in the eyes.[/p] [p]“I need your help,” you tell him. “There’s a ghost who’s following me around.”[/p] [p]“A ghost?” Digger says. His face turns white and he looks around nervously. “Where?”[/p] [p]“I don’t know,” you admit. “He could be back at my house. Or he could be right here.”[/p] [p]“[em]Here?[/em]” Digger cries.[/p]

[p]You decide to trust this guy. He’s a little weird looking, but he seems harmless. Even if he is a ghost.[/p] [p]“I’m John,” the boy says. “You’ve got to get away from here. That closet is filled with horrible spirits. Quick – close the door and hide in the basement!”[/p] [p]You do as he says, slamming the closet door hard. Then you run down the stairs to the kitchen. Then into the basement.[/p] [p]Why down here? you wonder, as you look around at the damp, grungy old basement beneath your grandmother’s house.[/p] [p]You’ve never liked this place. It’s cold. It’s dark. But even worse are the big, ugly crickets. They get in from outside through cracks in the basement walls. Then they hop all over the basement.[/p] [p]You hate them.[/p] [p]“Uh, how come we have to hide down here?” you ask.[/p] [p]That’s when you realize that John isn’t with you.[/p] [p]“John?” you call.[/p] [p][em]BAM![/em] You whirl around and see the basement door slam shut. [em]CLICK.[/em] And lock.[/p] [p]That ghost has locked you in![/p]

[p]Today is Friday.[/p] [p]So you think it’s your lucky day, huh? You think the caretaker is going to come and get you out of that coffin?[/p] [p]Think again. Today is Friday the [em]13th[/em]![/p] [p]If you don’t believe it, just look at the page number![/p] [p]Sure, the caretaker comes. But he has an ear infection. He can’t hear you screaming. And by the time he comes again next week, you’re not screaming anymore.[/p] [p]Sorry. Guess this wasn’t your lucky day after all![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]Congratulations! You picked the right Sarah. Sarah McGinnis. Born in 1918. Died in 1940, at the age of twenty-two.[/p] [p]You knew she was the right one – because the fencing ghost was a young beauty. So she must have died young. The other Sarah in the graveyard lived to be seventy-five years old.[/p] [p]Very clever of you to figure it out![/p] [p]Suddenly, you hear her voice. It fills your ears. “I am the Keeper of the Sword,” she calls to you from her grave. “Let my foil do the work. Let go!”[/p] [p]Let go? Weird, you think. But you do it.[/p] [p]As soon as the foil leaves your hand, it floats in midair. Then it plunges itself deeply into the earth.[/p] [p]Into Brandon Estep’s grave![/p] [p]“Aaaaahhh!” the ghost cries. His shimmering body begins to fade – and then disappears back into the earth.[/p] [p]Your eyes open wide and your mouth drops open as you gaze at an amazing sight. The coffins are creeping again – back to their original positions! You did it! The curse has been defeated![/p] [p]But there’s only one problem. Brandon’s ghostly body is gone – but his iron fist is still clutching your arm![/p]

[p]“Turn off that stupid light,” Elvira screams. “I’m trying to get some sleep!”[/p] [p]“Sorry!” You quickly flick off the light. But you don’t have any trouble seeing Elvira. She glows in the dark.[/p] [p]“I have to ask you something,” you tell her.[/p] [p]But she pulls the pillow over her face. This isn’t going to be easy. She’s one sleepy ghost.[/p] [p]Then you have an idea. You flick on the light again. Elvira sits straight up and lets out a piercing wail.[/p] [p]“Elvira,” you say, “I’ll turn off the light if you’ll answer one teeny question. Then you can sleep as long as you want. I promise.”[/p] [p]Her eyes begin to glow green again. But she looks very sleepy. Maybe she’ll be too tired to hurt you.[/p] [p]“Who’s the most powerful ghost in the graveyard?” you blurt out.[/p] [p]Elvira blinks a bit. “Hmmm,” she says. “I’d say Melvin Estep’s boy. He does tend to rule us with an iron hand.”[/p] [p]“The Estep boy?” you mutter. “But there are two of them. Melvin II, and Brandon. Which one?”[/p] [p]But Elvira doesn’t answer. She’s fast asleep.[/p] [p]And you promised you wouldn’t wake her up again![/p] [p]You always keep a promise. Hurry![/p]

[p]A ghost-hunter. That is [em]exactly[/em] what you need![/p] [p]But how are you going to find this MacFarling guy?[/p] [p]You dash out of your room and run downstairs as fast as you can. You rush back into the kitchen.[/p] [p]“Grandma,” you gasp, almost out of breath. “Do you know someone named MacFarling?”[/p] [p]“Oh, don’t go talking to me about Mac MacFarling,” she says. “That loon. He came around here last month. Told me he thought my house would be haunted soon. Said something about a curse, too. Can you imagine that? I don’t want you going anywhere [em]near[/em] that man.”[/p] [p]Uh, let’s face it. Granny’s not going to be much help.[/p] [p]So you race into the hall where she keeps her telephone books. You flip through the yellow pages. On a hunch, you look up “Ghosts.”[/p] [p]Bingo! There he is – under “Ghost Exterminations.”[/p] [p]Mac MacFarling. Ghost-hunter. There may be hope after all.[/p] [p]As long as you can get out of the house before Elvira finds out what you’re doing![/p] [p]Shhhh. Tiptoe out the door.[/p]

[p]“Aaaahhhh!” you scream as you feel yourself being pulled into the ground.[/p] [p]You can’t believe it, but it’s true. Somehow, magically, you are being pulled underground, as if your own body were made of filmy air, like the ghost’s.[/p] [p]It hurts. In fact, your whole body aches as it is dragged right into the ground. But only for an instant. Then you feel nothing.[/p] [p]You close your eyes. When you open them, you’re lying in a coffin – on top of a pile of old rotted clothes and bones![/p] [p]Your heart starts pounding wildly. You want to scream, but you don’t dare. You can already sense that the coffin has very little air.[/p] [p]And you don’t dare use it up. Not when you know that you’re in an old coffin ... six feet underground ... with no way out.[/p] [p]You’re buried alive![/p]

[p]“Uh, I’m g-going out-outside,” you stutter.[/p] [p]“That's nice,” your grandmother says, returning to her baking. “And when you come back in, I hope you’ll stop being so silly.”[/p] [p]She still doesn’t notice the ghost in the doorway.[/p] [p]You back up toward the door to the porch. You keep your eye on the ghost the whole time. And she keeps her glowing eyes on you. As soon as your hand reaches the doorknob behind you, you turn, fling open the door, and bolt.[/p] [p]But just as you start down the back porch steps, two hands grab your ankle.[/p] [p]“Aaaahhhh!” you cry as you trip. You sprawl headfirst down the stairs.[/p]

[p]It’s pitch-black in the house. But you’re okay. You’re not totally freaked out by the dark. Not yet, anyway.[/p] [p]“I mean it!” Lark yells. “You two are going to get it if you don’t turn those lights back on. And I mean now!”[/p] [p]You and Robin stand frozen in the kitchen. But before you can even move toward the circuit breaker box, the lights pop back on.[/p] [p]“Whoa! Oh, man!” you hear Lark and his friends yelling.[/p] [p]You hurry to the family room. That’s where Lark and his buddies were watching a movie on TV. You peek in the door.[/p] [p]What a sight! Popcorn all over the floor. Drinks spilled on the rug. Couch cushions tossed all over the room.[/p] [p]Lark spots you in the doorway. He glares at you and Robin – then lunges toward you. His hands reach straight for your throat.[/p] [p]You’d better run – quick![/p]

[p]“Help!” you cry. “Let me out!”[/p] [p]You turn to see if there’s another way out of the basement. Gross! Those disgusting crickets are hopping everywhere. There must be hundreds of them! The chirping is enough to make you crazy.[/p] [p]They hop from the window sills. They jump up and down the stairs. They pounce from the sink to the floor. From the floor to a chair. Jump! Jump! Jump![/p] [p]Ack! One lands on your head![/p] [p]“Yuck!” you scream. You swipe at your head. “Get off me!” More greenish-brown crickets hop around your feet.[/p] [p]You bang on the basement door. “Let me out of here!”[/p] [p]“Heh, heh,” you hear John snickering on the other side.[/p] [p]What a creep, you think.[/p] [p]Then it dawns on you.[/p] [p]“Hey, John,” you call through the door. “What’s your last name?”[/p] [p]“Luckmeyer,” the ghost answers.[/p] [p]Figures! Mac MacFarling was right.[/p] [p]“Uh-oh,” John Luckmeyer mumbles on the other side of the basement door. “Here comes trouble!”[/p] [p]What now? You have enough trouble already – in the form of a teenage ghoul.[/p]

[p]You try to grab at her sword. But you get a handful of nothing. The sword has no substance. It isn’t solid. It’s just air![/p] [p]The woman laughs. How can she do that without a head? “My sword is nothing without me,” she says mysteriously. “And I am nothing without my head. If you want the sword, you must find my head.”[/p] [p]You heard the woman.[/p] [p]Well, what are you waiting for?[/p] [p]Go find her head.[/p] [p]Now![/p]

[p]The ghost floats toward you and sneers in your face.[/p] [p]“Do I take it that you’re finally ready to make a deal?” the ghost asks.[/p] [p]Robin stares, open-mouthed at the ghost. This is the first time he’s actually seen the ghost in the flesh. Or rather, [em]almost[/em] flesh.[/p] [p]For a moment, Robin can’t speak. He just watches the airy creature floating around under the streetlamp light. Then Robin starts to smile. “Cool!” Robin says. “Totally cool!”[/p] [p]“You want my services,” the ghost goes on, “to scare those guys. And in exchange, I want your promise. You must agree to do anything I ask of you tomorrow.”[/p] [p]“Deal!” Robin says.[/p] [p]“Uh, I don’t know,” you reply. “What if he asks us to do something wrong? Something illegal or something?”[/p] [p]Robin shakes his head and leans over to you. “Then we just won’t do it,” he whispers. “Come on. Don’t you want to get back at Lark?”[/p] [p]Well? Don’t you?[/p]
p.next: If you make the deal with the ghost
If you still refuse

p.text: [p]Good work! You added right. The numbers in the date of Sarah Grayson’s death add up to 23.[/p] [p]But there’s just one problem. A big one. You’ve got the wrong Sarah![/p] [p]Figure it out. Sarah Grayson was born in 1820. She died in 1895. That made her seventy-five years old when she died.[/p] [p]But the ghost you saw – the fencing woman – was young. Remember? Long black hair. Ruby lips.[/p] [p]Not an old lady. A young one.[/p] [p]Which means, the Most Powerful Ghost has you in his powerful iron grip. And you’ve got no magical number to get out of it![/p] [p]Uh-oh.[/p] [p]Okay. You’ll get a break this time.[/p] [p]Go back to the graveyard and pick again. Choose the younger Sarah this time. Add up the digits in the year of her death. Then turn to that Page.[/p] [p]Revisit the graveyard.[/p]

[p]The Civil War soldier raises his huge sword. You quickly roll out of the way. The sword plunges into the ground. You scramble to your feet and run as the soldier wrestles the blade out of the dirt.[/p] [p]Where can you go? What can you do? Your heart pounds as you race down the road toward town. Maybe you can get help. Maybe the police will drive by. Maybe someone besides you will see this Civil War soldier and do something to save you![/p] [p]Maybe not.[/p] [p]You see two choices up ahead. There’s a small bridge that crosses a narrow river. If you run to the bridge, maybe you can hide under it.[/p] [p]You also see a small red barn across the street. It’s behind the farmhouse across from your grandmother’s house.[/p] [p]Another good hiding place.[/p] [p]Which is it? The bridge or the barn?[/p]
p.next: If you run to the bridge
If you hide in the barn

p.text: [p]“Why are you here?” you ask the ghost.[/p] [p]But your grandmother thinks you are talking to[/p] [p][em]her[/em].[/p] [p]“You know why I’m here,” your grandmother answers. “I [em]live[/em] here. Don’t be such a goose!”[/p] [p]For some reason, your grandmother can’t see Elvira.[/p] [p]You’ve always wanted to have a special skill. But ghost-spotting wasn’t what you had in mind![/p] [p]You try to think of a way to ask Elvira a question without having your grandmother think you’re completely crazy. But you can’t. So you keep staring at the ghost.[/p] [p]She glares at you a moment, then motions for you to follow her. You watch as she floats into the hall and up the stairs toward your room.[/p] [p]Follow a ghost? you think. Are you nuts?[/p] [p]Just the [em]idea[/em] gives you a chill.[/p]
p.next: If you follow the ghost
If you race out of this house fast – and GO HOME!

p.text: [p]You’re going to trust a ghost? No way! Who knows what he’s got up his ruffled sleeve? If this ghost doesn’t want you to see what’s in the closet, you bet it’s something that can help you un-haunt your grandmother’s house.[/p] [p]You peer into the dark closet. You don’t see anything.[/p] [p]You glance back at the ghost. He seems nervous. Good.[/p] [p]So you walk right into the closet.[/p] [p]AAA A A Ahhhhhh!!!!![/p] [p]There is nothing under your feet but air! You desperately try to grab hold of something – anything! – but it’s no use. You’re falling down, down, down into the darkness.[/p] [p]See, your grandmother has turned this closet into a clothes chute. She opens the door and tosses her dirty laundry in. The clothes fall straight down to the basement. That’s where the washer is.[/p] [p]And it’s a two-story drop.[/p] [p]Get the picture?[/p] [p]Now – how would you like to be washed? Hot water or cold? With or without bleach? Because it’s time to clean up your act, kid. You’re all washed up in the ghost-hunting business![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You plunge your sword into Melvin Estep II’s grave.[/p] [p]The moment the foil pierces the ground, Melvin Estep II rises up out of the earth.[/p] [p]Oooooohh ... really bad choice![/p] [p]He’s not the MPG – he’s the MHG! The Most Horrible Ghost![/p] [p]As the stinking mist that surrounds him begins to clear, you can see he has no face. There is just a skull – filled with rats! The squealing rodents pop out of his eye sockets. They run up and down his cheek bones, and in through his grinning mouth.[/p] [p]He rises up, up, up, towering over you. He’s huge! You sink to your knees in terror. “N-n-nooooo,” you whimper.[/p] [p]He is covered in shredded rags, teeming with bugs. Strips of rotting flesh fall from his skeletal body. He lifts his horrible skull head to the sky and lets out an unearthly moan. Then he fixes his rat-filled eye sockets on you![/p] [p]And then ... and then ... his bloody hands reach for your throat![/p] [p]Face it. What happens next is too gross, even for you![/p] [p]You’d better close the book for now, and open it again when you think you can survive all the way to[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You decide to play it safe – by asking Elvira for help.[/p] [p]You turn and race into the house. Your grandmother is watching TV in the den. You dash past her. She doesn’t even look up from her program. The eerie light from the television is the only light in the whole house.[/p] [p]You hurry up the back stairs to your room. You’ve got to find the MPG. And there’s only one person – or ghost – who might be able to help you.[/p] [p]You flip on a light in your small guest bedroom.[/p] [p]A piercing shriek shatters the night![/p] [p]Now what? Cover your ears.[/p]

[p]As soon as Digger hears that the ghost may be nearby, he panics.[/p] [p]He grabs a rope that’s tied around a big tree limb, runs to the edge of the platform, and jumps. He swings down to the ground in a speedy escape.[/p] [p]Then he runs into his house and locks the door.[/p] [p]Locks the door? Against a ghost?[/p] [p]How silly.[/p] [p]You’d laugh – if you weren’t still all sticky from the egg-yuck he poured on you.[/p] [p]Oh, well. Like most bullies, Digger turned out to be a coward.[/p] [p]So much for asking your worst enemy for help.[/p] [p]Stick to your best friend from now on.[/p] [p]Your best friend is waiting for you.[/p]

[p]You decide to get out of your grandmother’s house. On the double.[/p] [p]“Uh, Grandma,” you say. “I don’t feel well. In fact, I think I’m getting really sick. I think I should go home.”[/p] [p]“But dear,” your grandmother says. “You [em]can't[/em] go home. Not with your parents away on vacation.”[/p] [p]Well, it was worth a shot.[/p] [p]You swallow hard and glance over to where the ghost was standing. She’s gone.[/p] [p]Maybe you were imagining things. Maybe the gravestones [em]aren’t[/em] moving. Maybe you really [em]are[/em] sick![/p] [p]The best thing to do is go up to your room and lie down. You climb the stairs to the second floor. But as you reach the door to your room, you freeze.[/p] [p]There in the doorway is a terrifying sight![/p] [p]Hurry![/p]

[p]Your throat tightens in terror. Your heart pounds wildly. Both you [em]and[/em] your grandmother are cursed, now![/p] [p]Your granny can’t even [em]see[/em] the ghosts! She won’t be able to save herself. It’s all up to you.[/p] [p]You grip the sword so hard your hand cramps. You’ve got to stop the coffins from moving again. And you’ve got to do it now, before the final coffin moves into place and the curse is complete![/p] [p]But who is the Most Powerful Ghost?[/p] [p]“One more letter,” you mutter. Only one more letter is needed to spell out the message. The last letter in the word DIE – the letter E.[/p] [p]Then it hits you. The Most Powerful Ghost must be someone whose last name starts with an E![/p] [p]That’s it! You may live after all! You run through the graveyard, looking at the tombstones, searching for E’s.[/p] [p]You find three. Melvin Estep. Melvin Estep II. And Brandon Estep.[/p] [p]But which one is the MPG?[/p] [p]You could guess. Or you could go in the house and ask Elvira for help.[/p]
p.next: If you guess – take a stab at it
If you ask Elvira for help

p.text: [p]The bridge looks good to you. You can slip down the bank to the river and hide under it. You might be able to sneak around and change directions. Maybe you’ll lose the soldier after all.[/p] [p]But before you even reach the riverbank, you feel a heavy hand on your shoulder.[/p] [p]“Halt, traitor!” the soldier cries.[/p] [p]“No!” you scream, twisting away. You stumble a bit and lurch forward, out of his grasp. You keep running.[/p] [p]Finally you reach the bridge. But the soldier is right behind you. He swings his sword wildly at you – as if to cut off your head![/p] [p]“No!” you cry again, jumping backwards.[/p] [p]Uh-oh. Backwards wasn’t a good idea. You’ve just leaped off the bridge![/p] [p]And it’s a long way down. Oooh. That hurt.[/p] [p]You have a fifty-fifty chance of surviving that fall.[/p] [p][img src="../resources/flick.jpg" /][/p]

[p]Luckily, everything in your grandma’s small town is within biking distance. Twenty minutes later, you’ve biked over to Mac MacFarling’s office. Which happens to be located in his garage.[/p] [p]You knock on the side door of the garage.[/p] [p]“Come in!” a voice calls. You yank open the door.[/p] [p]Wow! you think when you see him.[/p] [p]Mac MacFarling has frizzy, kinky blond hair sticking out all over his head. He’s wearing six earrings, a nose ring, and a pair of heavy blackframed glasses with blue lenses in them. He’s about 20 years old.[/p] [p]So that’s why your grandma didn’t like him.[/p] [p]He’s cool![/p] [p]“What’s up?” MacFarling asks. “You look like you’ve just seen a ghost.” He laughs. “Sorry. Just a little ghost-hunting humor.”[/p] [p]You explain about Elvira, and that she told you the ghosts are going to take over your grandmother’s house.[/p] [p]“I’ve been expecting this,” MacFarling says, shaking his head. “I tried to warn your grandmother.”[/p] [p]“Can you help us?” you plead. His eyes are hidden behind the blue lenses. You can’t tell what he’s thinking.[/p] [p]Will Mac MacFarling help you?[/p]

[p]You run over to Melvin Estep’s grave and plunge your sword into the ground.[/p] [p]And wait.[/p] [p]Nothing happens.[/p] [p]Does that mean you’ve actually done it? Did you put an end to the curse of the creeping coffins?[/p] [p]You step back from the grave, leaving the sword standing straight up from the dirt. You take a deep breath. Could it really all be over?[/p] [p]Suddenly, one of the other two coffins – one of the other Esteps! – starts to move![/p] [p]Oh, no! You chose the wrong Estep![/p] [p]It’s all over, all right. All over for YOU![/p] [p]Before your astonished eyes, the headstone creeps across the graveyard. Within seconds, it reaches the third row. When the headstone stops creeping, the word DIE is complete.[/p] [p]And so is your adventure in this book. Complete. Finished. Done. As in ...[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p] [p]P.S. Here’s a hint. Next time you try to defeat the creeping coffins, ask Elvira for help. Don’t leave so much to chance![/p]

[p]“Help!” Robin screams as the knife drifts toward him.[/p] [p]Oh, no! Right beside the floating knife is the ghost-boy.[/p] [p]You grab the baseball bat and take a swing.[/p] [p]The bat goes right through the ghost’s see-through body. He laughs as if you tickled him.[/p] [p]Unfortunately, the bat comes out the other side of him and smashes right into Robin’s desk lamp.[/p] [p]Oooops.[/p] [p]The lamp flies off the desk and smashes onto the floor.[/p] [p]“What was that?” a woman’s voice calls from the hallway.[/p] [p]Uh-oh. Robin’s mom is on the way.[/p]

[p]You hear a booming [em]CRACK[/em]! In the next instant, the ghost of Brandon Estep rises up out of his grave.[/p] [p]Is he the MPG? Have you chosen the right Estep?[/p] [p]You peer at Brandon as he floats toward you. He’s a young guy wearing a black leather motorcycle jacket. With heavy metal spikes and chains. And a metal hand.[/p] [p]A metal hand?[/p] [p]A chill of terror runs through you. This must be him. The Most Powerful Ghost. The ghost with the iron hand.[/p] [p]You raise the foil again. But the ghost lunges at you – and grabs your arm with his iron hand.[/p] [p]Your arm freezes. You can’t move![/p] [p]For a moment, you panic. Then you remember what MacFarling told you. The date of Sarah’s death. It’s magic, somehow.[/p]
p.next: Is it 1895?

p.text: [p]Suddenly, MacFarling swings into gear. He picks up a strange electronic box and heads for the door. “Come on,” he says. “We’ve got to hurry. Let’s go!”[/p] [p]Finally – someone who can help you! You feel better already.[/p] [p]MacFarling jumps into his car – an old VW Bug. You hop on your bike. As you ride to your grandmother’s house, he drives along beside you. He rolls down the window and talks to you the whole time.[/p] [p]“Have the gravestones been moving around?” he asks.[/p] [p]“Yes!” you exclaim. So, you’re [em]not[/em] crazy! “Why are they doing that?”[/p] [p]“I’m not sure,” he says. “I’ve only seen it once before. But I think they’re moving into position to spell out some kind of message – or curse.”[/p] [p]Graves can spell? That doesn’t sound possible. But you’re ready to believe anything now. “How can we stop them?” you ask Mac.[/p] [p]“It won’t be easy,” he tells you.[/p] [p]You were afraid of that.[/p]

[p]Forget this, you decide. Digger is too much of a jerk. You’d rather face the ghost alone.[/p] [p]You climb down the ladder and start to head back home. Pretty soon, you realize that someone is walking beside you. You can hear his footsteps. You can feel the air moving, where he’s swinging his arm. You just can’t see him.[/p] [p]It must be the ghost![/p] [p]“Leave me alone!” you shout at him, although you can’t see a thing.[/p] [p]“Heh, heh,” he laughs under his breath. “You’ll never get away from me.”[/p] [p]Oh, yeah? you think. We’ll see about that.[/p] [p]Try to lose this guy.[/p]

[p]OUCH.[/p] [p]You land facedown at the bottom of the steps.[/p] [p]Good thing it wasn’t a long flight of stairs. You’re only bruised and scratched. You scraped your chin, but nothing’s broken.[/p] [p]“Ha, ha, ha!” you hear a boy’s voice say.[/p] [p]You turn toward the voice. You want to see the jerk who made you trip.[/p] [p]Hey – wait a minute.[/p] [p]There is no jerk behind you. You blink to be sure.[/p] [p]Yup. You’re sure.[/p] [p]There’s absolutely [em]no one[/em] standing at the top of the stairs! Or anywhere else![/p]

[p]You start to panic. The coffin feels – crowded. You try to sit up, but you bump your head. Ouch. Uh-oh. Was that... something moving?[/p] [p]What is it? you wonder. Your heart races. Snakes? Worms? Rats?[/p] [p]Something bumps your knee. You start banging on the coffin lid, trying to get out.[/p] [p]“Hey – hold still,” a voice says.[/p] [p]Slowly, the ghost-boy begins to materialize. He is squeezed in beside you. The coffin is so crowded now, you can hardly move.[/p] [p]“Take my hand,” the ghost-boy says. “Time to continue the journey.”[/p] [p]You stare at the ghost’s outstretched hand.[/p]
p.next: If you take the ghost-boy's hand
If you don't

p.text: [p]Your stomach turns at the sight of her bloody neck. Then you notice the ghost’s body is still hovering below you. It floats up the steps and somehow attaches to her head.[/p] [p]“Thank you,” she says once she’s in one piece. She hands you her foil. “I am the Keeper of the Sword. Take this – and use it as you will. Now I must return to my grave.”[/p] [p]You remember Mac MacFarling’s instructions. “Wait!” you call. “What’s your name?”[/p] [p]“Sarah,” she whispers as her form fades away.[/p] [p]Then she’s gone.[/p] [p]You run to the phone and dial MacFarling’s number. When he answers, you tell him you’ve got the sword.[/p] [p]“Good,” MacFarling says. “Listen carefully. Find her grave in the graveyard. Write down the year of her death. It’s a special number. You’ll need it. Then plunge her sword into the grave of the MPG. That’s the only way to keep the graves from spelling out the curse.”[/p] [p]“But how do I find the MPG?” you ask.[/p] [p]“Oops,” MacFarling says. “Call waiting. Got to go!”[/p] [p]He hangs up. Call waiting? you think. What a liar! He just doesn’t know how to help you find the MPG. Now what?[/p]
p.next: If you go to the graveyard
If you think the MPG will come to you

p.text: [p]A ghost fills the doorway. But this ghost isn’t just a filmy version of a five human being. This ghost isn’t like Elvira Martin.[/p] [p]This ghost is hideous! His whole face is grayish-blue. His tongue and eyes bulge out. He looks as if he died while being choked. Then his blueish hands reach out for you.[/p] [p]That does it. No way are you staying in this creepy haunted house for another minute![/p] [p]You run back downstairs to your grandmother. You beg. You plead. You cry. Then you pull out every trick in the book. Even the one where you fake a high fever by putting the thermometer on a light bulb.[/p] [p]Eventually, your grandmother gives in. She calls your parents. They cut short their vacation, come pick you up and take you home. They’re pretty steamed at you. But you don’t care. At least you’ve gotten away from that haunted house![/p] [p]You flop down on the bed in your room. That’s when you feel something poking you. Something in your bed![/p] [p]You sit up and stare at your blanket.[/p] [p]It’s sliding around on the bed – all by itself![/p]

[p]You turn and run out of the room, leaving Elvira snoring peacefully in your bed.[/p] [p]You head back to the graveyard. You’re going to have to take a chance on one of the Estep boys. And fast! Before the graves move again.[/p] [p]Only one letter left before the curse is complete. That’s what keeps going through your head.[/p] [p]When you reach the graveyard you are almost out of breath from running up and down the stairs so many times. But the sight that greets you nearly takes your breath away completely. You think you might faint.[/p] [p]The graveyard is filled with ghosts! Horrible ghosts. One of them – an old man with long, stringy hair – carries an ax. A woman sobs. A head without a body passes, then a body without a head. Each ghost is worse than the last![/p] [p]Then you remember the fencing foil in your hands. You raise the sword to fend them off. It works. They float all around the graveyard, but they don’t come near you.[/p] [p]You run straight for the Estep graves.[/p] [p]But which one? Melvin II or Brandon?[/p] [p]You’ve got to choose.[/p]
p.next: If you pick Melvin Estep II
If you pick Brandon Estep

p.text: [p]“Ha, ha,” the boy’s voice taunts again.[/p] [p]“Gotcha!” a girl’s voice joins in.[/p] [p]Right in front of your amazed eyes, a boy and a girl slowly begin to materialize.[/p] [p]When they finally take shape, you can see that they’re teenagers. But teenagers from a long time ago. The boy is dressed in a funny-looking black suit with a frilly white shirt and shiny black shoes. The girl is wearing a long, old-fashioned white linen dress. Her hair is braided and the braids are wrapped around her head three times.[/p] [p]The boy and girl look almost solid – but not quite. You can see right through them.[/p] [p]“Boo!” they shout at the same time. Then they double over with hysterical laughter.[/p] [p]Your heart is still pounding wildly.[/p] [p]Is this really happening? Or are you dreaming?[/p] [p]There's one way to find out. Pinch yourself.[/p]
p.next: If it hurts
If it doesn't

p.text: [p]“First,” MacFarling explains, “you’ll have to fight the Keeper of the Sword. That’s one of the ghosts. You need to get the special sword – and use it to stop the MPG.”[/p] [p]“What’s the MPG?” you ask.[/p] [p]“The Most Powerful Ghost,” MacFarling says. “It’s a term for the spirit who has control over a graveyard.”[/p] [p]“Once you have the sword,” Mac continues, “you must plunge it into the grave of the MPG. But you’ve got to hurry! Because when all the graves have moved into position and spell out the message – it’ll be too late! The curse will be complete. And after that, you’ll [em]never[/em] be able to get the ghosts back into their graves.”[/p] [p]Your head is spinning from what Mac just told you. But you nod as if you understand.[/p] [p]You’ve arrived at your grandmother’s house. MacFarling stops his car and hops out. You get off your bike and park it. MacFarling faces your grandmother’s house and switches on the funky electronic box he’s carrying. Red dials light up. Then you hear a loud beeping sound.[/p] [p]“Uh-oh,” MacFarling says. “Major trouble. Give me a dollar.”[/p]
p.next: If you give MacFarling a dollar
If you refuse to give him money

p.text: [p]The knife floats toward you and Robin. Quickly, you grab the needlepoint pillow. You hold it in front of you like a shield.[/p] [p]Are you crazy? You’re going to use [em]that[/em] pillow? The one Robin’s mother lovingly needlepointed for him? The one that took her seventy-four hours of finger-aching work to complete? You’re using it to block an attack from a flying [em]knife[/em]?[/p] [p]Oh, dear. We’re talking serious bad judgment here.[/p] [p]The pillowT, of course, is ripped to shreds. But that’s just the beginning. Just the first of many bad decisions you make in your life. For instance:[/p] [p]A few weeks later, you’re at a picnic. You drop a blueberry muffin onto a big red anthill. The fire ants swarm all over the muffin. You decide to pick it up and eat it anyway.[/p] [p]Your mother gives you a hundred dollars for your birthday. A beggar asks you for a quarter, but you don’t have any change. You tear off a piece of the hundred-dollar bill and give it to him instead.[/p] [p]When you grow up, you win a TV game show7. The prize is a new car! But the car is blue, and you hate the color. So you say “No thanks,” and give it back.[/p] [p]See the problem? Of course none of this will happen – [em]if[/em] you can learn how to choose more carefully.[/p]

[p]You cross your fingers and decide to take a chance on Brandon Estep. You run over to his tombstone and stand in front of it.[/p] [p]You hold the sword in both hands like a dagger, with the point down. Your hands tremble so much you’re afraid you’ll drop the sword. You tighten your grip and take a deep breath.[/p] [p]Then you raise the sword above Brandon’s grave and prepare to plunge it into the ground.[/p] [p]But something stops you.[/p] [p]What happened? Find out![/p]

[p]Time is running out. That last coffin could creep into place before you even cross over to a grave! Then it will be all over. For you and your grandmother.[/p] [p]You are too terrified to think.[/p] [p]So you decide to guess.[/p] [p]Well... what are you waiting for? Go ahead and guess.[/p] [p]Which one is the Most Powerful Ghost?[/p] [p]Melvin Estep? Melvin Estep II? Or Brandon Estep?[/p]
p.next: If you pick Melvin Estep
If you pick Melvin Estep II
If you pick Brandon Estep

p.text: [p]You follow Elvira to your room on the second floor. The moment you step into the bedroom, she slams the door.[/p] [p]Then she whirls around to face you. Her eyes turn green and begin to glow.[/p] [p]You back up, stumbling, and fall onto the bed.[/p] [p]“You little wretch,” she says. “I don't want any trouble from you!” Sparks seem to fly from her flashing green eyes. You shrink back into the pillows.[/p] [p]Then Elvira gazes around the room. “Yes, yes,” she says. “This wall do nicely.”[/p] [p]“Wh-what do you mean?” you stammer.[/p] [p]Elvira floats toward the bed. She hovers over you. “I’m taking over this room, now,” she tells you. “Get out!”[/p] [p]You would love to leave, but you are shaking too hard to get up. Besides, you have to find out what’s going on! Elvira is the only one who can explain it to you.[/p] [p]“Please,” you beg, “just tell me why you are here. And why are the graves moving?”[/p] [p]“Shut up!” she screeches. “And get off that bed. I want to lie down! I haven’t slept in a bed in fifty-one years!”[/p] [p]Uh-oh, you realize. You aren’t just dealing with a ghost here. You’re dealing with a ghost in a very bad mood![/p] [p]You'd better do what she says.[/p]

[p]The next day, you and Robin meet right after breakfast. The ghost shows up an hour later. Right on time.[/p] [p]“Okay,” the ghost says. “Here’s the deal. I want you to eat a plateful of worms.”[/p] [p]“Are you kidding?” Robin blurts out.[/p] [p]“Nope,” the ghost says. “You’ve got to eat worms. Stay here. I’ll get them.”[/p] [p]The ghost’s body suddenly forms into a funnel shape and disappears into the ground in Robin’s front yard. He looks like a human tornado vanishing into the earth.[/p] [p]When he zooms back up, the ghost has a handful of worms.[/p] [p]He walks over to Robin’s front porch. Sitting on the steps is a small plate.[/p] [p]“Eat these,” the ghost says, dumping the worms on the plate.[/p] [p]“Yuck!” Robin says. “No way!”[/p] [p]“If you don’t,” the ghost says, “I’ll haunt you for the rest of your life. Like this.” The ghost makes himself into an airy tornado again. But this time, the funnel flows into Robin’s head. It goes in one ear – and out the other![/p] [p]“Yeow!” Robin screams. “Okay! Okay! I’ll eat them!”[/p]

[p]You stare at the glowing ghostly face. Your mouth drops open as the face rises out of the moose head. The woman’s face floats up and hangs in midair, right in front of you.[/p] [p]“Thank you,” the head says. “You have released me from my trap.”[/p] [p]Her eyes are large and bright blue. Her ruby lips shimmer in the darkness. Her long black hair hangs down, falling below her neck.[/p] [p]Her neck? You glance at it – and try not to scream.[/p] [p]Torn flesh dangles from the bottom of her neck. Blood drips from the ragged edges.[/p] [p]Suddenly you realize what you’re seeing. It looks as if her head has been chopped off![/p] [p]Try not to faint.[/p]

[p]“Okay,” you say to the ghost. “I’ll do anything. Just help us!”[/p] [p]“Good,” the ghost-boy answers.[/p] [p]An instant later, you hear Lark go flying to the floor.[/p] [p]“Yeow!” Lark yells as he hits the rug hard.[/p] [p]You and Robin stop running. You turn and laugh.[/p] [p]“Quit snickering, you little twerps,” Lark snarls as he clambers to his feet. “You’re dead meat.”[/p] [p]He comes toward you and Robin, one hand clenched in a fist. The ghost-boy winks, and the rug flies out from under Lark. He sprawls on the floor again.[/p] [p]You and Robin laugh so hard you double over.[/p] [p]For the rest of the night, every time Lark or one of his buddies tries to come after you, the ghost pulls a prank. Nothing big. Nothing that would make Lark suspect anything. Just enough to keep the guys from bothering you.[/p] [p]You and Robin sleep very peacefully that night.[/p] [p]The next morning, when you get home, the ghost is in your room, waiting for you. “Okay,” the ghost says. “Time to keep your promise. Let’s go.”[/p] [p]Go? Go where?[/p]

[p]No doubt about it. You are definitely awake. This is really happening. Which means you are face-to-face with two teenage ghosts.[/p] [p]You stand up and brush yourself off.[/p] [p]“Who are you?” you ask, trying not to let your voice tremble. “What do you want? What are you doing here?”[/p] [p]“I’m Jane Luckmeyer,” the girl ghost says. “And this is my dearly beloved twin brother, John.”[/p] [p]John bows deeply. Then he sticks out his tongue.[/p] [p]“Oh, John,” Jane cries. “This will be so much fun!”[/p] [p]“Yes, dear sister,” John answers. “We haven’t had anyone to torment in ages.”[/p] [p]“An eternity!” Jane agrees. “But I’ve spent the time thinking of ever more horrible tricks and tortures.”[/p] [p]You don’t like the sound of that! Could these two creeps have something to do with the creeping coffins?[/p] [p]“Tell me something,” you say, hoping you sound casual. “Why have the coffins been moving around?”[/p] [p]But the twins don’t answer you. Instead, they cackle horribly and grin at you.[/p]

[p]You start to swing the rope, hoping to lasso the wild ghost stallion.[/p] [p]Are you kidding?[/p] [p]Do you know how long it takes to leam how to lasso?[/p] [p]And you don’t even have that rope tied in the right kind of knot, do you?[/p] [p]Admit it. Unless you’ve grown up on a dude ranch or within two hundred miles of a pack of wild stallions, you don’t have a flat chance of lassoing this crazed animal.[/p] [p]So...[/p]
p.next: If you were bom in Colorado, Montana, or Wyoming
If you were bom anywhere else

p.text: [p]You race across the lawn and over the hill to the small barn. You swing open the door.[/p] [p]Instantly, more than forty chickens flap down out of the rafters at you! Feathers fly everywhere.[/p] [p]“Aaaaa-choooo!” The feathers tickle your nose. They get in your mouth. You swipe at the downy tufts.[/p] [p]The clucking is so loud you cover your ears. Then you cover your [em]head[/em]. “Aaaaaahhhh!” you scream. The chickens are swooping toward your hair.[/p] [p]Huh?[/p] [p]Why are they swooping toward your hair? You’ve heard that [em]bats[/em] will fly at people and get tangled in their hair. But chickens?[/p] [p]There’s definitely something weird going on with these birds.[/p]

[p]You decide to ask your worst enemy to help you.[/p] [p]Digger Sukowski.[/p] [p]That’s the first name that pops into your head when you think about how to deal with this ghost.[/p] [p]Digger is a sixth-grader who lives a few blocks away. He’s a bully and a jerk, and you can’t think of anyone meaner or tougher. Perfect.[/p] [p]“Uh, wait right here,” you tell the ghost.[/p] [p]You dash out of the house and run all the way to Digger’s backyard. That’s where Digger and his friends have built a tree house.[/p] [p]The ladder leading up to the tree house has a sign on it.[/p] [p class="smallCapsAttribute"]NO TRESPASSERS. THIS MEANS YOU. CLIMB THIS LADDER AT YOUR OWN RISK![/p] [p]You swallow hard and put your foot on the ladder.[/p] [p]Keep climbing.[/p]

[p]You reluctantly hand MacFarling a dollar bill.[/p] [p]He folds the dollar in half twice. Then he jams it into a tiny slot of his electronic box. A minute later, the beeping stops. The box spits the dollar back out.[/p] [p]“Thanks,” MacFarling says. “The spirit counter was jammed.” He gives the dollar back to you.[/p] [p]Weird, you think. But it seems to have worked.[/p] [p]Then, MacFarling stares at the red dials on his machine.[/p] [p]“Bad news, kid,” MacFarling says finally. “By my count, there are ten ghosts in the house already. That’s way over my limit. You’re on your own.”[/p] [p]He starts back toward his car.[/p] [p]“Wait!” you call after him. “You can’t leave me here! Please! You have to help me!”[/p] [p]MacFarling hesitates for a minute. Then he shrugs. “Okay,” he says. “This is what I’m willing to do. I’ll help you make a map of the graveyard. Come on.”[/p] [p]A map of the graveyard? What for? you wonder.[/p] [p]But you don’t ask questions. You just follow Mac into the cemetery and do what he tells you. Au hour later, you’ve got a drawing of the first four rows of gravestones.[/p]

[p][em]Whoosh![/em] The rope snaps through the air with a swish! It flutters over Glory’s head. The ghost-stallion rears up with an angry whinny. You flick your wrist and give the rope a sharp yank. Bingo! You did it.[/p] [p]Talk about heavy-duty lassoing![/p] [p]Glory snorts and stamps his hooves, nearly lifting you off the ground. But you hang on. Using all your strength, you drag the ghost-horse down the stairs. You pull him into the den, where your grandmother is watching television.[/p] [p]“Grandma! Look!” you shout. “I’ve roped a [em]ghost[/em]-horse!”[/p] [p]Your grandmother gazes up from her television program and gives you a warm smile. Then she eyes the ghost-horse.[/p] [p]“Now, don’t expect me to fall for that,” she says. “I know all about the gizmos you kids have these days. What is that? Some kind of hologram? Or video game? See, I’m up-to-date.”[/p] [p]Hologram? Video game? Is she nuts?[/p] [p]With a twinkle in her eye, your grandmother reaches for the TV remote control – and aims it at the horse.[/p] [p]She pushes a button.[/p] [p]Showers of sparks shoot out of the remote. A cracking [em]BOOM[/em] shakes the house.[/p] [p]What has your grandmother done?[/p]

[p]“No way,” you say. “I’m not making a deal with a ghost!”[/p] [p]“Fine,” the ghost-boy says. “You’re on your own!” He vanishes.[/p] [p]Maybe this wasn’t such a great idea.[/p] [p]Lark and his friends catch up with you easily. What happens next isn’t pretty. By the time Lark and his friends are done, you and Robin are a mess.[/p] [p]You’re lying in the damp grass in Robin’s front yard. You’re bruised from being tackled. Your T-shirt and jeans are grass-stained. Your hair is a tangled nest. Lark used both sets of knuckles to give you “noogies.”[/p] [p]“Oooh,” Robin fumes. “I could strangle him!”[/p] [p]“No, you couldn’t,” you reply. “You’re not big enough. In fact, he strangled us.”[/p] [p]“True,” Robin admits. “But we’ve got to do something to get back at him. I wish that ghost would come back. Maybe he could scare the living bazookas out of my stupid brother.”[/p] [p]No sooner has Robin said the words when the ghost appears.[/p] [p]“You rang?” the ghost says with a sly smile.[/p]

[p]You didn’t feel that?[/p] [p]Uh-oh. Pinch again.[/p] [p]Nothing?[/p] [p]You’ve obviously fallen asleep while reading this book! You’ve gone bye-bye. To dreamland. You’re probably snoring, too.[/p] [p]The thing is, in your dreams you’ll probably be able to handle these ghosts.[/p] [p]But in real life? Well... that’s a different story.[/p] [p]So go ahead. Snooze on. Enjoy it.[/p] [p]We’ll see how well you survive – when you wake up![/p]

[p]Your heart races as you scoot away from the moving blanket. You press your back up against the wall. Something bumps into your foot. Then your knee.[/p] [p]“OW!” Something invisible pinched you![/p] [p]Little by little, the “something” begins to appear.[/p] [p]At first, it’s only a ghostly head. The head of a boy. He’s about twelve years old and he’s grinning at you.[/p] [p]“Surprise,” he says as his body, arms, and legs begin to materialize in front of you. He looks almost solid – but not quite.[/p] [p]“Who are you? Where ... where did you come from?” you finally blurt out.[/p] [p]“Wouldn’t you like to know?” he says. Then he floats over to the window and gestures toward your family’s car in the driveway. “Bumpy ride, wasn’t it?” he says with a laugh.[/p] [p]Bumpy ride? Oh, no! He hitched a ride with you from your grandmother’s house![/p] [p]You’ve got to do something to get rid of this ghost.[/p] [p]But what?[/p] [p]And who’s going to help you?[/p]
p.next: If you choose your best friend to help you
If you choose your worst enemy to help you

p.text: [p]“Okay,” you tell her. “I’ll find your head. Wait here.”[/p] [p]But where should you look?[/p] [p]You dash up the stairs to the attic. It’s the only room you haven’t been in since you arrived. And you definitely would have noticed a head if you’d seen one.[/p] [p]You rummage around in the attic. You search through everything. Twice. Trunks of old clothes. Piles of old furniture. Golf clubs. No ghost-head.[/p] [p]You glance around the dusty room. Think! There may not be much time left. If I were a ghost-head, where would I be? you ask yourself. You suddenly spot a large moose head sitting on the floor by a broken chair.[/p] [p]You kneel down to examine the moth-eaten moose head. Up close, it looks even wrorse. The antlers are cracked and one eye is missing. It is filthy and has a musty odor.[/p] [p]It’s not even human. But what choice do you have?[/p] [p]It’s the only head here![/p] [p]Besides – you’re in a big hurry. You’ve got to get the sword before the coffins creep again![/p] [p]You grab the moose head and race downstairs.[/p] [p]You only hope the Keeper of the Sword won’t be furious when she sees the head you brought her![/p] [p]Cross your fingers for luck.[/p]

[p]No deal, you decide. You’re not going to make a bargain with a ghost.[/p] [p]You wouldn’t even make a deal like that with your mom. Promise to do “whatever” she wants? You might end up raking leaves and washing her car for a year![/p] [p]“No, thanks,” you tell the ghost. “No deal. I don’t make promises I can’t keep.”[/p] [p]The ghost smiles at you. A nice smile. For the first time since you met him, he seems genuinely friendly.[/p] [p]“That’s what I wanted to hear,” the ghost says. “That you wouldn’t make a promise unless you really meant to keep it. I’ve been looking for someone honest like you for a long time.”[/p] [p]Then the ghost reaches into his pants pocket. He pulls out a gold coin.[/p] [p]“Take this,” he says, handing it to you. “And promise me that you will never spend it. The coin will bring you good luck as long as you never sell it, spend it, or give it away. But make sure you are not buried with the coin. Otherwise, your spirit will never rest. Like me, you’ll be forced to roam the earth looking for someone to give it to.”[/p] [p]You take the coin from him, and he sighs with relief. Then the ghost-boy vanishes completely ... and you never see him again.[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]Keep away from the Luckmeyer twins. That should be easy, no problem. Twins are pretty easy to spot.[/p] [p]Then it hits you – do they always stick together? Are they guys or girls? And how old are they? No way to know.[/p] [p]Hmmmm. Maybe this will be more difficult than you thought.[/p] [p]You slink into your grandmother’s house. You feel creepy, knowing the place is loaded with ghosts. And how are you going to find the Keeper of the Sword? You don’t have a clue. Your head swims as you wander up to the second floor.[/p] [p][em]BAM![/em] A door bangs open. It nearly hits you in the head.[/p] [p]You jump back, and peer into a hall closet.[/p] [p]“Don’t go in there!” a voice behind you warns.[/p] [p]You whirl around and see – a ghost! A teenager from another time. He’s dressed in an old-fashioned black velvet suit with a frilly white shirt. His hair is slicked back and combed neatly behind his ears. He’s smiling – but it’s a sneaky smile.[/p] [p]Should you listen to him?[/p]
p.next: If you stay out of the closet
If you see what's in the closet

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="127"][/p] [p]You stare down at the map of gravestones in your hands. You wonder how it can possibly help.[/p] [p]“Big trouble,” Mac says, peering over your shoulder. “The message is already almost completely spelled out.”[/p] [p]“What message?” you ask, puzzled.[/p] [p]“Look at these first four rows,” he says, pointing at the paper. “The rest of the graves don’t matter. That’s why I didn’t put them on the map. Take a pen and circle the first letter of the last name on each tombstone. It spells out a message! Don’t you see?”[/p] [p]No. You don’t see. And you won’t see – until you do it.[/p] [p]So do it.[/p]

[p]The Luckmeyer twins float down the steps toward you. And they both have an evil glint in their eyes.[/p] [p]Uh-oh. These two spell trouble. [em]Double[/em] trouble.[/p] [p]Run! you tell yourself. But which way?[/p] [p]If you run away from them, you’ll be running straight toward the graveyard.[/p] [p]But your only way back into the house is by getting past the Luckmeyer twins first. They’re floating closer and closer to you – and John is hiding something behind his back.[/p] [p]You freeze. You can’t decide what to do. You know John is up to something. And you know you’d better not stick around to find out what it is! But which way should you go?[/p] [p]Don’t think! Run![/p]
p.next: If you run toward the graveyard
If you try to slip past the twins and back into the house

p.text: [p]You’re trying to crawl out from under the sink, when the lights pop back on.[/p] [p]A moment later, Lark and his buddies zoom into the kitchen.[/p] [p]“What are you two jerks doing?” Lark asks.[/p] [p]“Nothing,” Robin says quickly.[/p] [p]“Yeah, nothing,” you chime in.[/p] [p]Lark looks at his friends and they all nod. You don’t like the way they’re smiling at you.[/p] [p]Uh-oh.[/p]

[p]Ick! Another cricket plops on your head.[/p] [p]“Let me out!” you yell again, pounding on the door.[/p] [p]Immediately, the door swings open.[/p] [p]Uh-oh. The ghost was right. Trouble [em]has[/em] arrived – in a big way.[/p] [p]It’s your grandma. And she’s steaming mad.[/p] [p]“What in heaven’s name are you up to?” your grandmother scolds.[/p] [p]You glance past her into the kitchen and see what she means. The whole place is a mess. Flour is scattered all over the floor. Pots and pans are stacked on the chairs and table. Every single item that was in the refrigerator is sitting on the kitchen counter.[/p] [p]“What on earth have you done?” your grandmother demands, pointing at the huge mess.[/p] [p]Behind her back, you see the ghostly John Luckmeyer with a big grin plastered across his smirking face.[/p] [p]Quick – what are you going to tell her?[/p]
p.next: If you decide to make up a story
If you tell the truth

p.text: [p]The book lands with the front cover down. Lucky you! You survive the fall off the bridge. But don’t kid yourself. You’re pretty bruised and scratched up.[/p] [p]“Owww ...” you moan, as you lie on the rocky banks of the river.[/p] [p]Mistake. You shouldn’t have moaned. Now the soldier knows where you are![/p] [p]In a flash, he jumps off the bridge and towers over you.[/p] [p]“Prepare to die!” he shouts.[/p] [p]Can’t this guy think of anything else to say?[/p] [p]Then he ... well... he ... you know. He finishes you off with one thrust of that beautiful, mother-of-pearl-handled, sapphire-encrusted sword.[/p] [p]Hey – don’t look so surprised.[/p] [p]We said there was a fifty-fifty chance of surviving the fall. We didn’t say anything about surviving this book![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You clutch the tree-house ladder so hard you get a splinter. The ladder is nailed to the side of the tree. There isn’t much space for your hands or your feet. The boards are wobbly and crooked. You don’t dare look down.[/p] [p]When you’re halfway up the ladder – too high to jump down, but not high enough to lift yourself onto the platform – Digger pops his head out of the tree house. He gives you a mean grin.[/p] [p]“Hey,” he says in a nasty voice. “Lookee what we got here. A trespasser!”[/p] [p]Then he leans over the edge of the platform with a bucket in his hands. He raises the bucket, then turns it upside down.[/p] [p]Directly over your head.[/p]

[p]“Uh, I was trying to make dinner for you, Grandma,” you say. If you told the truth, she’d think you were lying. Then you’d be in even bigger trouble.[/p] [p]“Well...” Your grandmother’s face begins to soften.[/p] [p]Then John Luckmeyer floats over to you. Before you realize what he’s doing, John picks up one of your grandmother’s best china teacups. He knocks it to the floor, right by your hand. The teacup lands with a horrible crash.[/p] [p]Oh, no![/p] [p]You start to open your mouth to explain. But then another ghost appears on the other side of you. This one is a girl. She’s wearing an old-fashioned, long white linen dress. Her hair is braided and the braids are wrapped around her head three times.[/p] [p]“Hello,” she says with a snicker. “I’m Jane Luckmeyer.”[/p] [p]Great, you think. Another one. Trapped between the Luckmeyer twins.[/p] [p]She picks up the china saucer that goes with the teacup John just smashed. The she tosses it like a Frisbee across the room. Somehow she makes it look as if you threw it. The saucer crash-lands at your grandmother’s feet.[/p] [p]“That’s it,” your grandmother says. “Go to your room!”[/p]

[p]You jump up from the bed.[/p] [p]Elvira lies down, neatly spreading her white satin dress on the covers. Her long red hair fans out across the pillow.[/p] [p]“Ahhhh,” she sighs. “A real bed.” She shuts her eyes.[/p] [p]You hope she doesn’t sleep too long. You have so many questions to ask. And you hope she’ll be in a better mood when she wakes up![/p] [p]She dozes for exactly two minutes. Then her eyes pop open. You notice they aren’t glowing green anymore.[/p] [p]“Ah,” Elvira says. “That’s better.”[/p] [p]Now that she’s awake, you’re not sure how to begin. You’re almost too freaked out to speak. But you have to know! “Why are the graves moving?” you ask. “What’s going on?”[/p] [p]“It’s the curse of the creeping coffins,” the ghostly woman answers. “And we’re moving into this house. All of us.”[/p] [p][em]All[/em] of us?[/p] [p]Gulp.[/p] [p]What does [em]that[/em] mean?[/p]

[p]You decide you need your best friend’s help. So you call Robin. He lives only two houses away.[/p] [p]Without even a goodbye to your mom and dad, you zoom out the front door. You run to Robin’s house as fast as you can.[/p] [p]“Hi!” Robin says. “That was fast. What’s up?”[/p] [p]“You’re not going to believe me,” you warn him.[/p] [p]“Try me,” Robin says, tossing three juggling balls in the air.[/p] [p]Robin has been trying to learn to juggle for six months. He just can’t get the hang of it.[/p] [p]“My grandmother’s house is haunted,” you explain quickly. “The coffins in the graveyard behind the house were creeping around. The ghosts escaped from their graves. And – ” you pause and take a deep breath. “And one of them followed me home.”[/p] [p]Robin stares at you as if you’re crazy. He lets all three balls drop to the floor with a [em]thud-thud-thud.[/em][/p] [p]“Yeah, sure. Right,” he says sarcastically.[/p] [p]A moment later, all three juggling balls rise up from the floor. To your amazement, they start juggling themselves![/p] [p]Then one of them flies right at Robin – and hits him in the face![/p]

[p]Maybe your grandmother was right. Maybe this guy can’t be trusted. Maybe he’s a scam artist.[/p] [p]“What do you want a dollar for?” you ask him.[/p] [p]But before he can answer, the funky electronic box beeps one more time. Real loud.[/p] [p]Then all of a sudden, a lid on top flips open – and a small plastic hand pops out![/p] [p]Cool! you think. You’ve seen these things before.[/p] [p]It’s a gag bank. Your uncle had one, but his used dimes. It was a small black plastic box with a slot on top, just like MacFarling’s gadget. When you put a dime in the slot, a lid would fly open and a plastic hand would pop out. The hand would grab the dime and pull it into the box. It cracked you up.[/p] [p]But why is MacFarling playing around with a trick bank? You’re supposed to be hunting ghosts.[/p] [p]“Give me a dollar!” Mac screams frantically.[/p] [p]But before you can answer him, the plastic hand reaches farther out of the box – and grabs you by the throat![/p] [p]In the next instant, it pulls you into the box![/p] [p]You don’t think your uncle’s bank worked like this.[/p] [p]Too bad you didn’t have a dollar when you needed it![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]Robin’s mom is furious when she sees the broken lamp.[/p] [p]How furious?[/p] [p]Let’s just say you and Robin will be mowing lawns for a long time to pay for the lamp.[/p] [p]But the good news is, the ghost seems to have vanished! Maybe Robin’s mom scared him off.[/p] [p]“You weren’t kidding,” Robin says. “There really is a ghost!”[/p] [p]“I tried to tell you,” you say to him. “Listen, can I sleep over? The ghost is probably back at my house, just waiting to get me!”[/p] [p]“No problem,” Robin tells you. “You’ll be a lot safer here.”[/p] [p]Don’t bet on it.[/p]

[p]“Where are we?” you ask the ghost-boy.[/p] [p]“Oh ..he says. “You know.”[/p] [p]No, you think. I [em]don’t[/em].[/p] [p]You pass an elaborate gold-framed mirror hanging in midair. You look at your reflection. And gasp![/p] [p]Your legs! Your arms! They’re gone! You stare at the “you” in the mirror. You can see the furniture behind you – right through your own body![/p] [p]Maybe it’s a trick mirror! You glance down at yourself. It’s no trick. Your legs are transparent.[/p] [p]Your heart drops into your see-through feet as you realize the truth. You’re a ghost, now, too![/p] [p]Someone suddenly calls your name. You whirl around – and see your old piano teacher. Mrs. Hatfield. She was a sweet old lady, about ninety years old. She died last year. You have to admit you haven’t missed her much. You never liked taking piano lessons.[/p] [p]“Oh, there you are!” Mrs. Hatfield exclaims. “Come with me. I want you to play some scales.”[/p]
p.next: If you go with Mrs. Hatfield
If you refuse

p.text: [p]It’s true. Your feet have turned to stone. So has the rest of you.[/p] [p]Help! you want to cry out.[/p] [p]But you can’t speak. Stone lips don’t move.[/p] [p]“I warned you,” Jane says quietly.[/p] [p]“Ha, ha,” John says, laughing and pointing at you. “You’re stuck!” He wags a finger in your stony face.[/p] [p]You’d like to bite him, but you can’t. You can’t do anything. You’re a statue. You’ve turned to solid stone.[/p] [p]“See what happens when you walk among the dead?” John says. “You should have listened to Jane. Don’t [em]ever[/em] walk with a dead person into a graveyard. It’s the most dangerous thing you can do.”[/p] [p][em]Now[/em] they tell you![/p] [p]GO in, if you can. Go on and try it. Try to turn the page, stony-fingers![/p]

[p]You press the mute button. Instantly, the Neanderthal man disappears.[/p] [p]Phew. Close one, you think.[/p] [p]Then you have an idea. You press the mute button again. Yup. It works just as you thought it would. The ghost of the Neanderthal reappears. And when you press it again, he disappears. You can keep switching back and forth.[/p] [p]Now you see him – now you don’t![/p] [p]Needless to say, this is a cool toy. You and your grandmother play with it for a few days. Then you call the local newspapers. They come out and write a story about you. Pretty soon, you’re famous. Every computer game company in America and Japan wants to buy your invention.[/p] [p]The amazing remote-controlled hologram machine![/p] [p]You tell them the truth. You have no idea how it works. But for ten million dollars, they can have the remote [em]and[/em] the house. And they can try to figure it out for themselves.[/p] [p]When the deal is made, you leave the remote and the house behind. But there is still one more “remote” in your future. A [em]remote[/em] island in the South Pacific! That’s where you and your grandmother fly off to. Why? Just in case the company figures out you’ve sold them a house full of ghosts![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You take off running. Top speed.[/p] [p]You dash down the street and zoom around the corner. Then, as fast as you can, you duck into a drugstore.[/p] [p]Maybe the ghost didn’t notice where you went.[/p] [p]You hope.[/p] [p]The drugstore owner glances up as you come in. “May I help you?” he asks.[/p] [p]“No,” you say. “I’m just looking.”[/p] [p]You head over to the magazine stand in the back of the store. It’s tall and you’re hoping the ghost won’t see you behind it. You spend about twenty minutes browsing through the comics.[/p] [p]When you think the coast is clear, you start to leave.[/p] [p]“Hold it right there,” the drugstore owner says. He comes out from behind the counter and grabs your arm. “I’m calling the cops on you!”[/p] [p]Huh? Since when is reading comics against the law?[/p]

[p]“I found the head!” you call out when you reach the landing. You clutch the moose nervously. You peer into the darkness, trying to find the headless ghost.[/p] [p]The woman’s body materializes on the steps below you.[/p] [p]“Good,” her voice says. You still can’t figure out how she can talk. “Just set it down right there – on the stairs.”[/p] [p]Really? you think. This is going to work? Maybe the ghost hasn’t seen the moose head, yet. What will she do when she discovers what you’ve done?[/p] [p]Trembling, you set the moose head down on the bottom step. You hold your breath.[/p] [p]For a moment, nothing happens.[/p] [p]Then the moose head begins to shake. At first it just rocks back and forth a little. But soon it starts to vibrate wildly.[/p] [p]The moose head begins to glow, as if there were a light inside it. Then a ghostly woman’s face appears [em]inside[/em] the moose head! You can’t believe it! But there it is – the face of a beautiful young woman trapped within the dusty old moose head.[/p] [p]WOW! You did it! You actually found her head![/p]

[p]“Okay,” you tell the ghost. “It’s a deal.”[/p] [p]“Good,” the boy says with a strange smile.[/p] [p]“But you’ve got to really scare Lark,” Robin warns, pointing a finger at the ghost.[/p] [p]“No problem,” the ghost answers. “Wait here.” You and Robin stand on the front lawn in the moonlight. You watch the ghost as he floats into the house – right through the wall! A few minutes later, the screaming starts.[/p] [p]“Aaaaaah! Hellllpp! Aaaaaahhhhh! Noooooooo!” you hear Lark and his friends crying from inside. They sound as if they’re face-to-face with sheer terror. Scared out of their minds.[/p] [p]Robin is really happy. But as the screaming continues, you start to worry. “You don’t think he’s really hurting them or anything, do you?” you ask.[/p] [p]“I don’t know,” Robin says. “Maybe we should go in there and stop him.”[/p] [p]“Yeah,” you say, swallowing hard.[/p] [p]The two of you start toward the front door. But just then the screams stop.[/p] [p]The ghost floats out through the front door. ‘Okay,” he says. “I’m done. See you tomorrow at ten.”[/p]

[p]You take the ghost-boy’s hand.[/p] [p]As soon as you touch him, a chill runs through you. His hand feels like ice.[/p] [p]“Hold on,” he says. “Here we go!”[/p] [p]Before you know what’s happening, he starts to move away – floating sideways. His thin transparent body is floating right through the coffin – and he’s taking you with him![/p] [p][em]BOOM![/em][/p] [p]Inside your head, you hear the sound of fireworks. You close your eyes and see fireworks, too! At the same time, you feel your body being pulled through the coffin walls.[/p] [p]When the fireworks stop, you slowly open your eyes.[/p] [p]You instantly wish you hadn’t.[/p] [p]You are lying on a dirt floor. Over your head is a dirt ceiling. The cave-like room is filled with an eerie green light. Stairways leading nowhere are covered in plush carpeting. Cobwebs drip from furniture. Laughs and moans echo all around you.[/p] [p]But the worst news is – you are surrounded by ghosts. That’s right, you are in an underground world of living dead people. All of them floating around. Some dance, some play games, some wander aimlessly. But all of them are, well, dead.[/p]

[p]The lights are out. All the lights. And you’re scared to death. You can’t move.[/p] [p]You stand there frozen in Robin’s kitchen, in the dark.[/p] [p]“Come on,” Robin says, grabbing your arm. “We’d better get out of here. Lark’s coming!”[/p] [p]“No,” you try to say. But you can’t even speak. Your heart is pounding too hard. Your legs are locked stiff.[/p] [p]Robin tries to drag you out of the kitchen. But your hand grips the kitchen counter.[/p] [p]“Oh, okay,” Robin says. “We’ll hide under the sink.”[/p] [p]Quickly, he squats down and opens the two cabinet doors that lead to the space under the kitchen sink. He starts to crawl in.[/p] [p]Good idea, you think. Let’s hide from the dark![/p] [p]Huh?[/p] [p]No. It doesn’t make any sense. But you’re so scared, you don’t know [em]what[/em] you’re doing![/p] [p]So you squat down and crawl into the cramped space with all the drain pipes and stuff.[/p] [p]That’s when you see them. Two small eyes – glowing at you in the dark![/p]

[p]“Where are you going?” you ask the ghost-boy. “And what’s your name?”[/p] [p]“You’ll see,” he answers.[/p] [p]“I’ll see? I’ll see what your name is?” you ask.[/p] [p]“Sure. It’s on my gravestone,” the ghost replies.[/p] [p]A cold mist swirls around the ghost-boy, making you shiver. You notice the ghost’s eyes have turned hard. He’s not so friendly, now.[/p] [p]You really regret making that promise.[/p] [p]“Let’s go,” he orders, leading the way.[/p] [p]You have no choice. You’ve seen this ghost in action. If you don't do what he says, he’ll probably haunt and torment you for the rest of your life.[/p] [p]You follow him to an old graveyard. This one’s on the far side of town. At the edge of the graveyard, the ghost stops. He puts out his hand to keep you from taking another step.[/p] [p]“Wait here, until I reach my tombstone,” he tells you. “When you see me disappear, stand on top of my grave.”[/p] [p]Hmmm. Sounds creepy. Are you going to do it?[/p]
