If no

p.text: [p]You decide to find out who is making all the noise in the attic.[/p] [p]You glance around for something to use as a weapon.[/p] [p]Let’s see. Your grandmother has doilies. A rocking chair. Pillows. Not much to choose from. Finally you pick up a piece of rope that your mom used to tie your suitcase closed. You have no idea how a piece of rope could help, but it’s all you’ve got.[/p] [p]The pounding of heavy feet over your head makes you wonder if you’re making a mistake. But you have to find out who – or what! – is in the attic. Slowly, you climb the stairs. Dust from the attic steps stirs in the air and makes you sneeze.[/p] [p]“Ah-choo!” you say loudly.[/p] [p]All at once, the stomping stops.[/p] [p]The door to the attic bangs open.[/p] [p]“NO!” You scream when you see what’s standing at the top of the stairs.[/p]

[p]MacFarling never told you what to do about an iron hand![/p] [p]“Help!” you scream. “HELP!”[/p] [p]But who can help you in a graveyard?[/p] [p]You try to yank the metal hand off your arm. But you can’t do it. Its grip is too strong.[/p] [p]“Help!” you cry again. But your scream dies in your throat. You are too terrified to make a sound. Because the hand is moving![/p] [p]The iron fist creeps along your arm. It clutches your flesh so hard you can already feel the bruises. The glinting metal hand travels up to your throat. Horrified, you watch helplessly as the iron fingers open with a clanking sound and then snap around your neck. It’s strangling you! You’ve got to do something fast![/p]

[p]No way. You’re not going to practice your piano now.[/p] [p]“No, thanks,” you tell Mrs. Hatfield. “I never liked piano lessons. And now that I’m a ghost, I’m never going to practice again!”[/p] [p]Mrs. Hatfield looks around at the other ghosts. They all smile and nod. Then she breaks into a huge grin.[/p] [p]“Good!” Mrs. Hatfield says. “You passed the test!”[/p] [p]“What test?” you ask, feeling confused.[/p] [p]“You never were any good on that piano,” she says. “In fact, you were simply terrible. I just wanted to be sure you didn’t waste any more time with it. The world has enough bad musicians. It doesn’t need another one.”[/p] [p]Hmmph! you think. But you know she’s right.[/p] [p]“Okay,” Mrs. Hatfield says, motioning to the ghost-boy. “You can take this one back.”[/p] [p]Before you know what’s happening, the ghost-boy pulls your hand again. This time, he drags you toward the mirror – and right into it. You close your eyes, and once again you hear fireworks. But halfway through the journey, he lets go of your hand. When you open your eyes, you are standing aU alone in the cemetery. And you know you have finally come to[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You go into the house to look for John Luckmeyer. After all, you think he might be the Keeper of the Sword.[/p] [p]Are you [em]serious[/em]?[/p] [p]Luckmeyer? You think [em]he[/em] might hold the most powerful sword? The sword that can destroy the MPG? And didn’t MacFarling warn you to stay away from that practical joker?[/p] [p]Uh-oh. If you think that, you may have a serious problem.[/p] [p]Take this test to find out:[/p] [p class="centered"]THREE TRUE-OR-FALSE QUESTIONS TO DETERMINE IF SOMEONE IS CRAZY[/p] [ol] [li]Spinach is an alien life form and should therefore never he eaten for dinner.[/li] [/ol]

p.text: [p]So far everything seems normal. Just like all the other times you’ve spent the night at Robin’s. In fact, you and Robin are having a great time. Even Robin’s older brother Lark is less obnoxious than usual.[/p] [p]Yeah, Robin and Lark. Robin’s last name is Birdsey. His parents like cute stuff like that.[/p] [p]Lark is having a sleepover party. His friends are in eighth grade. They think they’re way cool. And they are. Until nine o’clock. When suddenly all the lights in the house go out.[/p] [p]“Hey!” Lark yells at you and Robin. “Quit playing with the circuit breakers, you little twerps. Or else!”[/p] [p]Uh-oh.[/p] [p][em]You[/em] didn’t touch the circuit breakers. Neither did Robin. And his parents aren’t home.[/p] [p]Who’s left?[/p] [p]That’s right – the ghost.[/p] [p]And all the lights are out.[/p] [p]What now?[/p]
p.next: If you're afraid of the dark
If you're okay in a pitch-black house

p.text: [p]You do as the ghost says. You wait at the edge of the graveyard until he stops at a grave. Then you watch as his whole airy body seems to disappear into the ground![/p] [p]Okay, you think. This is it. Time to walk over there and stand on that grave.[/p] [p]You gulp loudly. You scratch your head. You burp.[/p] [p]Hey – enough stalling. Get over there![/p] [p]Your legs tremble as you walk to the grave and peer at the headstone. Then, still shaking, you stand on the grave. The tombstone says [span class="attribute"]James T. Reddson III.[/em] 1875-1910.[/p] [p]Hmmm. You do some quick math, and realize this guy was thirty-five when he died. This can’t be the kid’s grave, you realize. He lied to you![/p] [p]Before you can figure out what you should do, you hear a terrible rumbling. You fling out your arms, trying desperately to keep your balance as the ground begins to shake. The earth all around you rises and rolls in waves. Your eyes open wide as you watch the ground beneath your feet break apart.[/p] [p]Get me out of here, you think. But you’re too late.[/p] [p]A hand – the ghost-boy’s hand! – suddenly pops up out of the dirt and grabs your ankle![/p]

[p]“Oh, no!” you gasp.[/p] [p]You stare at the map – and at the message spelled out on the gravestones.[/p] [p class="smallCapsAttribute"]YOU WILL DI SOON.[/p] [p]So that’s the terrible message the graves are moving around to spell. And is the “you” you? Or is the curse directed at your grandma? Either way, it’s super bad news![/p] [p]“Mac,” you say. “There’s only one letter missing! Only one more coffin has to creep into place and then...”[/p] [p]“Then the curse wall be complete,” Mac says. He turns and walks back to his car.[/p] [p]“Wait!” you call after him.[/p] [p]He stops, but only long enough to pull out a business card. “Here,” he says. “Call me after you defeat the Keeper of the Sword. Then I’ll tell you what to do next.”[/p] [p]Then he jumps back in his VW Bug, leaving you standing in front of your grandmother’s house. “Oh,” he calls as he starts to drive off. “Two things to remember. Be sure to find out the name of the Keeper of the Sword. And stay away from the Luckmeyer twins!”[/p] [p]The Luckmeyer twins? you think.[/p]

[p]You can’t believe your eyes.[/p] [p]At the top of the attic stairs is a ghost horse! A huge, wild stallion, with its mane flying behind it. Foam drips from the stallion’s mouth. Its eyes are wild with fury.[/p] [p]The horse backs up a step, then rears up and lets out a terrible angry cry. Its hooves crash down, clomping loudly on the attic floor.[/p] [p]Wait a minute, you think. Was there a horse buried in the cemetery?[/p] [p]Then you remember. An extra-large grave, with a headstone that read:[/p] [p class="smallCapsAttribute"]HERE LIES GLORY. TOO WILD FOR THE RIDERS OF THIS WORLD.[/p] [p]No kidding, you think. This horse looks like a killer![/p] [p]Quick. You’re going to be trampled – unless you do something.[/p] [p]But what?[/p]
p.next: If you jump on Glory and ride him
If you use the rope to lasso him

p.text: [p]You turn on your heels and run as fast as you can – straight toward the graveyard![/p] [p]“Hey!” Jane calls to you. “Don’t go in there!”[/p] [p]Oh, sure, you think. She just doesn’t want you to escape! You keep running.[/p] [p]But the minute you cross the property line – from your grandmother’s yard into the cemetery – a terrible chill runs down your spine.[/p] [p]Your whole body feels as if it has turned to ice. Or stone. You stop running and begin to move very slowly.[/p] [p]“I am walking among the dead,” you hear yourself say in a flat voice. Why did I say that? you wonder.[/p] [p]“You are walking among the dead,” John says right behind you. He and Jane float around the graveyard.[/p] [p]“I am a prisoner of the graves,” you hear yourself say.[/p] [p]“You are a prisoner of the graves.” John and Jane repeat your words together.[/p] [p]You take a few more steps. Your legs are so stiff, you can barely move.[/p] [p]You look down at your feet – and scream.[/p] [p]“Aaahhh!” you moan. “My feet have turned to stone!”[/p]

[p]Okay. So you’re not a natural-born cowboy.[/p] [p]You’re just a kid with a dumb rope in your hands – and a foaming-at-the-mouth horse about to trample you on the stairs.[/p] [p]You wave the rope at the horse, using it like a wimpy whip. You feel so stupid, you’re surprised the horse doesn’t start laughing.[/p] [p]But someone does laugh! You turn around and see a ghostly cowboy floating your way.[/p] [p]“Worst attempt I’ve ever seen,” the cowboy says. You stare at him with your mouth open. He takes the rope from you.[/p] [p]“You want to lasso Glory, you’re gonna need some lessons from an expert. Me!” The cowboy gives the rope a sharp yank and, [em]FLICK[/em], it lands around the stallion’s neck.[/p] [p]“Cool!” you cheer. “Can you show me how to do that?”[/p] [p]“Sure thing, pardner,” the cowboy answers. “Now here’s what you have to do.”[/p] [p]For the next hour the ghost-cowboy teaches you all about lassoing.[/p] [p]When you think you're ready, try to lasso Glory all by yourself.[/p]

[p]“Robin,” you whisper, “I hate to tell you this, but we’re hiding under the sink with a Lanx.”[/p] [p]“A what?” Robin asks.[/p] [p]“A Lanx! A Lanx!” You are practically shouting. “It’s like a Grool, but worse!”[/p] [p]Robin stares at you. Then he shakes his head. “You are getting too weird. Even for me.”[/p] [p]“It looks like a potato,” you continue, “but it has really sharp teeth!” You have to make Robin believe you! You are in terrible danger.[/p] [p]“That’s it,” Robin says. He pops open the cabinet door. “Fun’s over. You know,” he adds as he crawls out from under the sink, “I didn’t really believe your ghost story, either. I was just playing along.”[/p] [p]You gaze sadly at Robin as he heads out of the kitchen. You have a feeling you’ve just lost your best friend.[/p] [p]“Heh heh heh,” you hear behind you.[/p] [p]You glance back at the glowing eyes. They look even brighter than before.[/p] [p]You thought being followed home by a ghost was a problem. Wait until you try living with a Lanx![/p] [p]“Heh heh heh.”[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You race out to the graveyard. You’ve got to find the fencing woman’s grave – fast! Then it hits you. You only know her first name. Sarah.[/p] [p]Sarah who?[/p] [p]You run up and down the rows of tombstones, searching for a grave marked Sarah. Naturally, you find two.[/p] [p]One is Sarah Grayson. Bom in 1820. Died in 1895.[/p] [p]The other is Sarah McGinnis. Bom 1918. Died 1940.[/p] [p]It’s up to you. Which is the right Sarah?[/p] [p]Think very carefully.[/p] [p]Then pick one.[/p] [p]You balance the sword under one arm and feel around in your pockets. You pull a broken pencil from your jeans. You glance down and find a crumpled gum wrapper on the ground. You grab it and with shaking fingers you write down the year of Sarah’s death.[/p] [p]And hope you chose correctly![/p] [p]Have you written down the date of Sarah's death? Good. Because something terrifying is happening behind you. You really don’t want to keep your back turned. So put down your pencil and turn back. If you dare...[/p]

[p]“Get away from me!” you shout. You duck and twist, trying to avoid the diving chickens. They squawk and flap their wings. One bird lands on your shoulder. Its claws dig into your clothes.[/p] [p]“Hey!” you yell at it. You try shaking it off, but it clings to you. You notice the other chickens hovering nearby.[/p] [p]You reach up to grab the stupid bird but something stops you. Could it be? Is the chicken [em]smiling[/em] at you?[/p] [p]You peer closely at the bird.[/p] [p]Uh-oh.[/p] [p]That chicken isn’t smiling, it’s baring its teeth.[/p] [p]But chickens don’t have teeth. And they sure don’t have fangs.[/p] [p]That’s right. Fangs. Guess what? These aren’t ordinary chickens. These are vampire chickens. And the bird on your shoulder is leaning closer. And closer. And closer.[/p] [p][em]CHOMP![/em][/p] [p]Being bitten by a vampire chicken puts you in a fowl mood. Oh, well. Better cluck next time.[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]“No,” you tell the ghost. “I’ve kept my promise. And look where it got me!”[/p] [p]“Suit yourself,” the ghost-boy says. He vanishes.[/p] [p]So, now what are you going to do, huh? Just lie there in the coffin and rot?[/p] [p]That’s one choice.[/p] [p]Got any other ideas?[/p] [p]Okay, sure. You could start screaming at the top of your lungs. Maybe – just maybe – someone will hear you.[/p] [p]Like who?[/p] [p]Like the cemetery caretaker. He shows up once a week. On Fridays.[/p] [p]Well? What day is this?[/p]

[p]You decide to duel with the woman in the fencing costume. She’s not as big as the soldier.[/p] [p]“En garde, yourself!” you cry. You notice that as soon as you shouted at the woman, the soldier-ghost vanished.[/p] [p]The fencer glides toward you, approaching slowly. You feel around desperately for something you can use as a weapon. The whole time you keep your eyes glued to the sharp tip of her sword. Or rather, her [em]foil[/em]. That’s what a fencing sword is called.[/p] [p]The fencer keeps coming toward you, slowly ... slowly. Beads of sweat break out along your upper lip. The tip of the foil wavers slightly, as if the fencer were deciding on the perfect spot to stab you.[/p] [p]Finally your fingers grasp something leaning against the wall. An umbrella. It’s not much. But it’ll have to do.[/p] [p]You grab it and strike a fencing pose,[/p] [p]“En garde!” you shout again.[/p] [p]The fencer freezes, her foil raised.[/p] [p]Then in a flash, she lunges at you![/p] [p]Quick! Find out if you're still alive.[/p]

[p]You jump back, trying to make room for Robin. He’s backing up faster than a pizza delivery guy who’s missed the address.[/p] [p]But the knife keeps coming anyway.[/p] [p]Quick – you have to do something to help him! You spot a baseball bat in the corner of the room.[/p] [p]Hmm. Good choice. If you have good aim.[/p] [p]But there’s also a huge needlepoint pillow on Robin’s bed. One that his mother made for him. Maybe you should use it as a shield.[/p] [p]Choose your weapon.[/p]
p.next: If you use the baseball bat
If you use the pillow as a shield

p.text: [p]“Ow!” Robin cries out. His hand flies up to his cheek, where the juggling ball hit him.[/p] [p]Your mouth falls open. This is terrible. The ghost must have followed you down the street![/p] [p]“Why did you do that?” Robin yells. “That really hurt!”[/p] [p]“But I didn’t do it!” you reply. “It was that ghost!”[/p] [p]Robin stares at the juggling balls. They’re just lying on the floor now. The ghost is nowhere in sight.[/p] [p]“Yeah, right,” Robin says. “Like I’m really going to believe in ghosts. Come on, how did you do that?”[/p] [p]Before you can answer, there’s a knock on Robin’s bedroom door. He walks over and opens it.[/p] [p]“Yikes!” he screams.[/p] [p]Floating in the doorway, in midair, is a long sharp carving knife.[/p] [p]And it’s pointed right at Robin’s heart![/p] [p]Robin is backing up fast, so you’d better move back, too.[/p]

[p]Using the back door you quietly slip into the house. Then you sneak up the back staircase to the second floor. You peek around the corner carefully – you don’t want to run into the Luckmeyers. When you are sure the coast is clear, you start up the stairs toward the attic.[/p] [p]As soon as you step into the stairway, you see a huge soldier standing at the top of the third floor landing![/p] [p]His uniform is old-fashioned. Civil War, you guess. And judging from the medals pinned to his gray jacket, this guy knows what he’s doing.[/p] [p]And what he’s doing right now is pulling a sword from its holder.[/p] [p]The sword is about five feet long. The handle is mother-of-pearl, encrusted with sapphires. The blade gleams. Even in the darkness you can see that it’s dangerously sharp.[/p] [p]The enormous soldier points the sword at your heart. “Do not advance one more step – unless you are willing to die!” he booms.[/p]

[p]“Get him, Sparkle!” you shout.[/p] [p]The hideous ghost floats toward you. The worms wriggle through his matted hair. This guy is gross![/p] [p]“Woof.” Sparkle barks right in the ghost’s disgusting face.[/p] [p]Nothing happens.[/p] [p]“Uh, again, Sparkle!” you command. But Sparkle tucks his tail between his legs, whimpers, and slinks away.[/p] [p]“Sparkle, come back,” you call. But it’s no use. That’s one terrified mutt. You turn to face the wormy ghost.[/p] [p]The ghost brings his face right next to yours. The worms wiggle from the ghost to you. They crawl in your mouth, up your nose, in your ears.[/p] [p]Is it possible to die from being totally grossed out?[/p] [p]Well, even if it isn’t, the worms make it impossible for you to breathe. Making this[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You can’t take your eyes off the sword. The longer you stare at it, the more your legs shake.[/p] [p]Then it dawns on you. This soldier must be the Keeper of the Sword![/p] [p]So what are you going to do? Run and hide?[/p] [p]Definitely![/p] [p]Trembling in fear, you start to back up. That’s when you feel a sharp point sticking you in the back. Right between your shoulder blades.[/p] [p]“Ouch!” you cry out, turning around.[/p] [p]Big trouble. Behind you is [em]another[/em] ghost. And this one’s dressed in a fencing costume. White canvas pants. A wire mesh mask. Leather gloves.[/p] [p]“En garde!” the new ghost says. The voice echoes all around you. From the voice, you know this ghost is a woman.[/p] [p]Then you realize something. She has a sword, too![/p] [p]Two ghosts. Two swords. Both dangerous. But only one has the sword you need.[/p] [p]Which one?[/p]
p.next: If you think the fencer is the Keeper of the Sword
If you think it’s the soldier

p.text: [p]The book landed with the front cover face up. That means you don’t survive the fall from the bridge.[/p] [p]Sorry.[/p] [p]So now you are a ghost, roaming the neighborhood, haunting everyone in sight. And for a while, scaring people is fun.[/p] [p]But soon you get tired of people screaming whenever you appear. And some people can’t even see you. For some reason, not everyone is able to see ghosts.[/p] [p]You begin to understand why the Luckmeyer twins played pranks and practical jokes. It’s a goof![/p] [p]So you start doing it, too – playing tricks on people. You move their coffee cups while they’re not looking. You raise their windows right after they’ve closed them. You wrinkle their clothes while they’re ironing them. You steal key pieces from jigsaw puzzles when people aren’t looking.[/p] [p]Then one day, you go too far – you do something really evil. You go through a GIVE YOURSELF GOOSE BUMPS book with a black felt marker and cross off all the page numbers![/p] [p]The only problem is, it was this book. The only one you’re in.[/p] [p]Which is why, sad to say, this is really and truly...[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]“Wha-what do you mean, [em]all[/em] of you?” you manage to stammer.[/p] [p]“You ask too many questions!” Uh-oh. Elvira’s eyes flash green again. “Don’t get in our way and [em]maybe[/em] we will let you live.”[/p] [p]She soars up over your head and glares down at you. “And don’t you go talking to that ghost-hunter MacFarling, either!” Elvira adds.[/p] [p]In the next instant, she floats backward and disappears into the wall.[/p] [p]MacFarling? A ghost-hunter?[/p] [p]You are startled by loud clumping footsteps above you. You glance up at the ceiling. The light fixture is shaking. It sounds as if a whole crowd wearing clunky boots is stomping around in the attic.[/p] [p]Who could it be?[/p]
p.next: If you want to find out about MacFarling
If you want to find out who’s in the attic

p.text: [p]Okay, time to face facts. Today is not Friday.[/p] [p]The caretaker is not going to show up for a long time.[/p] [p]And guess what else? If he did show up, he probably wouldn’t hear you screaming anyway.[/p] [p]After all, you’re six feet underground.[/p] [p]Looks like you’re running out of choices. Maybe you’d better go take the cold, cold hand of that ghost-boy after all.[/p]

[p]You run up the steps, darting sideways to get past John.[/p] [p]But he grabs you with one hand. Whoa! For a see-through guy, John is strong! In his other hand he dangles a ghostly snake before your eyes.[/p] [p]YIKES! The snake hisses in your face. Its fangs drip ghostly poison.[/p] [p]John and Jane laugh at your terrified expression. John shoves the hissing snake into your face again. Its tongue darts in and out between its razor sharp fangs.[/p] [p]Can a ghost snake hurt you? The pain where John is clutching your arm makes you think it probably can![/p] [p]You swallow hard and lurch away from him. Luckily, he and Jane don’t try to follow.[/p] [p]With a yank, you pull open your grandmother’s kitchen door.[/p] [p]YIKES, AGAIN! That other ghost – Elvira – is standing right there![/p] [p]“So you came back,” she snarls. “You may regret that!”[/p] [p]She turns and floats into the hall. Then she floats up the stairs.[/p] [p]Toward [em]your[/em] room.[/p] [p]Follow her.[/p]

[p]Robin picks up a worm from the plate. He stares at it. Just as he opens his mouth to take a bite, you hear someone snickering.[/p] [p]You glance around.[/p] [p]The bushes seem to be moving.[/p] [p]Quickly, you inch over toward the sound.[/p] [p]“He’s eating it!” you hear a voice whisper. A voice that sounds exactly like Robin’s brother,[/p] [p]Lark. “Ha, ha. The little twerp! I hope he chokes!”[/p] [p]“Yeah,” another voice says. “That was a cool deal we made with the ghost. Pretending to scream for an hour. And then he promised to make your brother eat worms the next day.”[/p] [p]Oh, no! you realize. You’ve been tricked![/p]

[p]You decide not to follow the ghost into the cemetery.[/p] [p]Why should I? you think. Just because I promised him I would?[/p] [p]You feel a little guilty about breaking your promise.[/p] [p]But as soon as the ghost disappears into the grave, you turn and run as fast as you can. All the way back home.[/p] [p]And you know what happens next?[/p] [p]Nothing.[/p] [p]That’s right. Nothing. And you never see another ghost again, as long as you live.[/p] [p]Years later, you tell your children all about your grandmother’s haunted house. About how a ghost followed you home. And haunted your best friend’s brother’s party. And you promised to follow him into the graveyard the next day, but didn’t do it.[/p] [p]Your children think you’re making it up, of course. But you know the truth.[/p] [p]Because every time you walk past a graveyard, you hear voices calling you. Accusing you. The voices of the ghost-boy and all his ghost friends. “Yooooooou,” they call. “Yooooou lied!”[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You press the button to change the channel again.[/p] [p]Unfortunately, you’ve run out of channels.[/p] [p]Even with Direct TV, a satellite dish, and all the cable channels in the universe combined, you can only go so far. Then you hit the end of the line.[/p] [p]257,000 channels – and nothing on.[/p] [p]So when you press the button for a higher channel, nothing happens. The Neanderthal man doesn’t change into anything else.[/p] [p]And you know what that means. It means you’ve just been hit in the head with a big ugly club![/p] [p]Ow. That hurt. And he’s taking aim again![/p] [p]Oh, well. That’s what you get for trying to survive this ugly episode by [em]pushing buttons[/em]![/p] [p]Seriously – didn’t it ever occur to you to just [em]duck[/em]?[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You decide to tell your grandmother the truth.[/p] [p]Wait a minute. Are you kidding?[/p] [p]You’re going to tell your grandmother that her house is haunted? That the big mess in the kitchen was a ghoulish prank? That there are so many ghosts around that Mac MacFarling, professional ghost-hunter, wouldn’t take the case?[/p] [p]You’re going to tell her all that?[/p] [p]Oh, REALLY?[/p] [p]Well just try it. Go tell your parents – or your grandparents – the same story. See if they believe you.[/p] [p]HA![/p] [p]When they get done laughing, you can start reading again on PAGE 71.[/p] [p]And try to learn a little lesson from this: You should always try to tell the truth. But sometimes the truth is too unbelievable to tell. Like anytime ghosts are involved.[/p] [p]That’s when you have to be a little creative ...[/p]

[p]So there you are, standing like a stone statue in a graveyard. You probably think this is the end, don’t you?[/p] [p]Well, it [em]could[/em] have been.[/p] [p]But a few days later, the graveyard caretaker comes by. He notices you – and realizes that you don’t belong there. Pretty soon, he figures out he could get a lot of money for a stone statue of a kid![/p] [p]So he backs his pickup truck into the cemetery and loads you on it. Then he drives away. He sells you to a garden shop that carries stone statues to put in people’s gardens.[/p] [p]A few months later, your grandmother walks into the shop and sees you standing there. She can’t believe her eyes – a statue that looks exactly like her missing grandchild! She buys you and brings you back to her house.[/p] [p]Unfortunately, your grandmother’s house is still haunted. But for some reason, she has never noticed the ghosts floating all around.[/p] [p]But you notice them. Especially the two ghosts you hate the most – the Luckmeyer twins! They spend the rest of eternity teasing you and pinching your stone nose. And you just have to stand there and take it until[/p] [p class="end"]THE END OF TIME[/p]

[p]You don’t like the prickly feeling in the back of your neck. You turn around slowly – and gasp.[/p] [p]The coffins have moved again![/p] [p]You can tell because you’ve wandered to the front of the graveyard. You are standing by the first row. The row that spelled out YOU in the curse. The row that used to have only three tombstones.[/p] [p]But now the front row is crowded with graves. Seven of them. Four more coffins have creeped into place![/p] [p]You glance toward the back of the graveyard and notice new empty spots. It’s true! The tombstones are spelling again![/p] [p]Your heart pounds as you run along the row, reading the four new names – trying to see what the new initials will spell out.[/p] [p]Bannister. Oswald. Thackery. Hamilton.[/p] [p]B ... O ... T ... H.[/p] [p]Oh, no![/p] [p]Now the message reads YOU [em]BOTH[/em] WILL DI SOON![/p]

[p]The ghost-boy grips your ankle so hard, you think he might break your bones.[/p] [p]You try to yank your leg away, but it’s no use.[/p] [p]The ghost-boy won’t let go. And he’s strong. Super strong.[/p] [p]Oh, no! you realize. He’s not just holding on to your ankle. He’s pulling you right into the ground with him![/p] [p]He’s pulling you down into the grave beneath your feet![/p] [p]Hang on.[/p]

[p]The metal hand clutching your throat is squeezing the life out of you. You don’t have much time left.[/p] [p]Then you see it. The sword. It has lifted itself out of the ground – and it’s once again floating in midair. The sword helped before. Maybe it can help you again.[/p] [p]Stretching your arm as far as you can, you reach for the sword. You nearly topple over, but you manage to grab the handle. Now that you have the sword, you’re not sure what to do with it. But you have to do something – the fingers are tightening... tightening...[/p] [p]You’ve got to get some space between your throat and the metal fingers! You bring the sword up to your neck. Trying to avoid slicing your own throat, you jostle and jiggle the sword through the fingers of the metal hand. Finally, the blade pokes up through the iron fist. The tip is just under your nose. The sword is jammed between your skin and the cold metal of Brandon Estep’s hand.[/p] [p]The iron hand releases your throat. The sword and the hand clatter to the ground. It’s over.[/p] [p]Well, maybe not.[/p] [p]The moment the sword hits the dirt, you hear a sound. An almost deafening sound.[/p] [p]Hold your ears.[/p]
[p]You should not continue reading this book.[/p] [p]Close it – and wait for the guys in the white coats to come and take you away. Don’t worry.[/p] [p]You’ll be fine after a nice long rest...[/p]

[p]There may be hope for you.[/p] [p]But you’ve got to face facts. John Luckmeyer is not the Keeper of the Sword. The Keeper of the Sword is a much scarier, much more terrifying ghost.[/p] [p]Face reality, and choose again.[/p]

[p]You decide the enormous Civil War soldier must be the Keeper of the Sword. You face him and the fencing-ghost behind you vanishes.[/p] [p]You can’t seem to lift your eyes from the sharp blade of the soldier’s weapon. “Are y-y-you the K-Keeper of the Sword?” you ask him, your voice trembling.[/p] [p]“NO!” he bellows.[/p] [p]Then he lunges forward and charges at you![/p] [p]“Aaaaahhh!” you scream in terror. You turn and run for your life. Down the stairs. Out the front door. Into the night.[/p] [p]You don’t look back. But you don’t have to. You can hear the ghostly soldier behind you. His heavy boots thud against the ground.[/p] [p]You dash across the front yard, toward the road. You manage to put some distance between you and the ghost. But then something grabs your foot![/p] [p][em]SMACK.[/em] Your hands hit the gravel at the side of the road as you fall flat on your face. You glance down to see what made you fall. Just a gnarled tree root.[/p] [p]“Prepare to die!” the soldier shouts as he stomps toward you.[/p]

[p]“What did I do?” you ask the store owner.[/p] [p]“You know perfectly well,” the owner says. “Shoplifting!”[/p] [p]Then he reaches around behind your back – and pulls out a comic book![/p] [p]“Huh?” you say. “Where did that come from?”[/p] [p]“Don’t try to kid me,” the owner says. “I could see it plain as day.” He smacks you on the forehead with the rolled-up comic book. “Did you really think you’d get away with tucking this into the waistband of your jeans? It wasn’t even under your shirt! I don’t know how you balanced it that way. It was hardly tucked into your pants at all.”[/p] [p]You are dumbfounded. Speechless. You didn’t steal that comic book! Honest![/p] [p]But then you hear the ghost snickering in your ear.[/p] [p]“Welcome to your new career,” the ghost says.[/p] [p]To make a long story short, the ghost follows you the rest of your life – getting you into trouble every step of the way. He takes money from your mother’s purse – and plants it in your dresser. He steals cars – and parks them in [em]your[/em] driveway. Everywhere you go, things disappear. And people blame you.[/p] [p]In fact, you probably didn’t pay for this book, did you? Well, just for that, you’re facing ...[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]“I guess Brandon’s ghost is finally at rest,” you say.[/p] [p]You gaze around you and see that the tombstones are all back where they belong. In fact, the whole graveyard looks kind of sleepy and peaceful.[/p] [p]“Oh, don’t be a goose,” your grandmother scolds. “There are no ghosts. Next, you’ll be telling me that the ghost of Elmyra Martin is taking a nap in your room!”[/p] [p]Elvira? You’d forgotten about her. But you figure when the other ghosts returned to their graves, Elvira did, too.[/p] [p]Your grandmother yawns. “Come on,” she says sleepily. “This is way past both our bedtimes.”[/p] [p]You and your grandmother go inside. You say goodnight and climb the stairs to your bedroom.[/p] [p]What a day! you think, flopping down on the soft bed.[/p] [p]“Watch it!” A familiar voice echoes through the room. A lump under the comforter slowly materializes.[/p] [p]Elvira![/p] [p]“Don’t hog the covers,” she snaps. She yanks the blanket under you so hard you roll right out of bed.[/p] [p]You’ve heard of bad roommates, but this is ridiculous! Well, you’ll just have to learn to get along. Because Elvira is here for eternity. Your days of having your own room have come to an[/p] [p class="end"]END[/p]

[p]You and Robin watch as the ghost forms himself into a funnel-shaped tornado again.[/p] [p]“Uh-oh,” Robin whispers to you. “If he does what I think he’s going to do, I wouldn’t want to be Lark. It hurts!”[/p] [p]In the next instant, the ghost blows himself into Lark’s head. He flows into one ear – and out the other.[/p] [p]“Yeow!” Lark screams. “Okay okay okay okay okay! I’ll do it!”[/p] [p]Robin turns to you and slaps you five. “Cool!” he says.[/p] [p]“Not so fast,” the ghost says. “You’ve still got some eating to do.”[/p] [p]“We do?” you say.[/p] [p]“A deal’s a deal,” the ghost says.[/p] [p]Right.[/p] [p]Ah, well. Maybe eating worms won’t be so bad in[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]The tip of the blade slices right through your neck![/p] [p]Okay, you can open your eyes now. Good news. You’re still alive. And you never felt a thing. You know why?[/p] [p]The fencer is a ghost. She’s not solid. She’s airy. See-through. And so is her weapon.[/p] [p]You pick up your umbrella and slice back. You lunge forward, poking your umbrella right between her ribs.[/p] [p]But your umbrella has the same effect on [em]her[/em] that her foil has on you! None.[/p] [p]There’s no point in keeping up this duel. Neither of you can win. You put down the umbrella.[/p] [p]“Are you the Keeper of the Sword?” you ask her.[/p] [p]“Yes,” she says. She reaches up and pulls off her mask.[/p] [p]You gasp and your stomach turns over.[/p] [p]She doesn’t have a face. Because she doesn’t have a [em]head[/em]![/p] [p]“Yes. This is the sword you need,” she tells you. You wonder where her voice is coming from. “And I will give it to you – if you can find my head.”[/p] [p]Is she kidding? What are the chances?[/p] [p]Maybe you should just try to grab the sword.[/p]
p.next: If you grab the sword
If you look for her head

p.text: [p]“I know what you’re thinking,” Mrs. Hatfield says. “You’re afraid you can’t get to the gold, now that you’re here, with us.”[/p] [p]You nod.[/p] [p]“But don’t worry,” she says. “You didn’t come here the ... the regular way. So you can go back to the world of the living anytime you want.”[/p] [p]Your eyes light up. “I can?” you say. “How?”[/p] [p]“Oh, it’s easy,” Mrs. Hatfield says. “Didn’t you ever see [em]The Wizard of Oz[/em]?'[/p] [p]Huh?[/p] [p]“[em]You[/em] know,” she goes on. “All you have to do is click your heels together three times and say 'There’s no place like home.’ It worked in the movie. It should work here, too.”[/p] [p]Is she kidding? Well, what have you got to lose?[/p] [p]So, you give it a try. You click your sneakers together three times and say, “There’s no place like home.” When you open your eyes again, you’re in your own bed at home.[/p] [p]With the map in your hand![/p] [p]Hey. Your mom always said those piano lessons would pay off someday, didn’t she? Looks like she was right![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You hurry into the hall and start up the stairs toward your room. But something stops you.[/p] [p]A terrible chill in the air. A cold so cold, you feel as if it will freeze your blood and bones.[/p] [p]An instant later, thirteen howling ghosts appear. They float out of the walls and come toward you. They are all shapes and sizes, but they have one thing in common.[/p] [p]They are all terrifying![/p] [p]NO! you want to cry. This can’t be happening![/p] [p]Your knees shake so much, you almost fall down. But somehow you manage to run. Ghostly arms reach for you as you race out the front door. Into the front yard, where the sky is growing dark.[/p] [p]For the next ten minutes, you huddle under a big tree, trying to think.[/p] [p]Mostly, you just think one thing. GET ME OUT OF HERE![/p] [p]But you know you can’t go home. Your parents are away on vacation. Besides, you can’t leave your grandmother here all alone. Not with those creeping coffins.[/p] [p]Which means you’ve got to go back into that house. You’ve got to get rid of the ghosts. And you’ve got to find the Keeper of the Sword. Before it’s too late![/p]

[p]You decide to sit down and wait. If the MPG is so powerful, you think, then let him come to me![/p] [p]With the fencing foil in your hand, you plop down on a chair in the hall. Sparkle, your grandma’s mutt, comes and sits at your feet. You feel better knowing someone’s on your side – even if it is just an old dog.[/p] [p]A loud knocking begins inside the walls. A moment later, a ghost floats through the wall toward you. A creepy ghost without eyes![/p] [p]“Ooooo,” he moans sadly. He hovers closer.[/p] [p]You stand up, and hold out the foil. Your hands tremble. Is this the MPG?[/p] [p]Sparkle jumps to his feet, too. “Arrf! Arrf-arf!” the dog barks.[/p] [p]The ghost instantly disappears![/p] [p]Did Sparkle do that? “Hey, Sparkle,” you say, patting the dog’s head. “Good job!”[/p] [p]A minute later, you hear a terrible groaning sound. Another ghost appears in the hall. This one has worms crawling all over his face![/p] [p]A low growl begins in Sparkle’s throat.[/p] [p]Will it work again? Will Sparkle scare away the ghost?[/p]

[p]As the ghost-horse charges at you, you grab his mane and pull yourself onto his back.[/p] [p]Yee-haw! Ride ’em, cowboy![/p] [p]There’s only one problem. An instant later, the horse turns left.[/p] [p]And a left turn from your grandmother’s attic stairway goes only one place. Straight [em]through[/em] the stairway wall.[/p] [p]And then outside![/p] [p]Uh-oh.[/p] [p]You grip Glory’s mane even tighter and shut your eyes.[/p] [p]Okay, you think. Makes sense. A ghost-horse can ride through walls.[/p] [p]But can you?[/p] [p][em]BAM[/em].[/p] [p]Guess not.[/p] [p]And that’s why, when you open your eyes again, you’re still riding Glory! You and your ghost-horse charge through the moonlit sky. As you will – for eternity.[/p] [p]It said on his tombstone, Glory was “too wild for the riders of this world.” But face it, you aren’t of [em]this[/em] world anymore. Those days have come to an[/p] [p class="end"]END[/p]

[p]You stare into the dark space under the sink. The two small eyes stare back at you.[/p] [p]There’s something alive under there![/p] [p]Hey, wait a minute.[/p] [p]Something fishy is going on here.[/p] [p]You’re in the wrong GOOSEBUMPS book! You’re in [em]It Came from Beneath the Sink[/em]![/p] [p]And you have a terrible feeling you know what is staring at you with those glowing eyes.[/p]

If you think the eyes belong to a Lanx

p.text: [p]This time, the remote control changes the Egyptian pharaoh king into a Neanderthal man.[/p] [p]You recognize him from all the science books at school. Big hairy guy. Slumpy shoulders. Long arms. Huge wooden club.[/p] [p]Huge wooden club?[/p] [p]Yup.[/p] [p]And he’s swinging it at your head![/p] [p]Think fast![/p]

If you try the mute button

p.text: [p]“Stop!” you cry out, running over to Robin. “Don’t eat the worms! It’s a double-cross!” “What?” Robin asks, looking confused. Luckily he was too grossed out to take a first bite.[/p] [p]You explain what you’ve overheard. “Your brother’s in there!” you say, pointing to the bushes. “He’s tricked us! He made a deal with the ghost. He pretended to scream last night – even though the ghost wasn’t doing [em]anything[/em] to him!” Robin still looks confused. Until Lark and his friends come out laughing. “Ha, ha,” they say. “You have to eat worms because of us. You twerps got what you deserved.”[/p] [p]“What are [em]you[/em] laughing about?” the ghost says to Lark. “You made a deal, too. I agreed to make your brother eat worms. But in return, you promised to do whatever I asked.”[/p] [p]“Yeah,” Lark says. “So what?”[/p] [p]“So now it’s time to keep [em]your[/em] part of the bargain,” the ghost says to Lark. “And here it is: You have to spend the night with a dead rat – in an open grave!”[/p] [p]“Oh, right,” Lark says. “And just how are you going to make me do that?”[/p] [p]“Easy,” the ghost says with a small laugh.[/p]

[p][em]BONG! BONG! BONG![/em][/p] [p]What is that? Some kind of clock tower?[/p] [p][em]BONG... BONG ... BONG ... BONG ...[/em][/p] [p]The chimes strike twelve times.[/p] [p]At exactly midnight, the iron hand and the sword vanish – and your grandmother appears in the doorway of her house.[/p] [p]“Why, listen to that!” she exclaims. “It’s the clock tower in the church. That clock hasn’t chimed in years!”[/p] [p]“Really?” you say, your eyes growing wide.[/p] [p]Your grandmother nods. “Not since Brandon Estep died. He crashed his motorcycle in this graveyard. Wild boy. But he loved that clock tower. He had helped his father build it. So everyone said Brandon haunted this place, and that’s why the clock wouldn’t chime. Of course that’s a lot of nonsense.”[/p] [p]Nonsense? No way, you think.[/p] [p]“They tried to fix the clock a million times,” your grandmother goes on. “But it never worked. I wonder why it started chiming now?”[/p] [p]You’re pretty sure you know the answer to that.[/p]

[p]“Aaaaah,” you shriek. “It’s a Grool!”[/p] [p]“What are you talking about?” Robin whispers.[/p] [p]“Th-th-those eyes,” you stammer. “They belong to an evil Grool!”[/p] [p]You are in big trouble now. The Grool loves to make terrible things happen. As if our luck wasn’t [em]already[/em] bad.[/p] [p]“You’re crazy,” Robin tells you. “And if you don’t shut up, Lark and his buddies are going to find us.”[/p] [p]“You thought I was crazy when I told you about the ghost,” you hiss at Robin. “And now look at us.”[/p] [p]Robin sees your point. “Okay.” He sighs. “Let’s check out this Grool.”[/p] [p]You move aside so that Robin can see the glowing eyes for himself. He reaches for the Grool.[/p] [p]“Don’t touch it!” you warn him. But it’s too late. You can’t watch. You shut your eyes.[/p] [p]“So this is a Grool!” Robin laughs. He holds something in front of your face. You open one eye. Then you open the other eye.[/p] [p]Robin is holding a little kitten.[/p] [p]“Oooops,” you say sheepishly. “Sorry. I guess I’m a little stressed. That happens to me when I meet ghosts.”[/p]
